output: Thank you, Mr. President. I very much welcome the approach that we describe in the white paper, namely, to trace the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting illnesses.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, we are falling into a very one-sided approach, whether we are discussing the new CAP, food labeling, or even, in some areas, the White Paper.
we are, in effect, attempting to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
I believe that assuming there are good and bad foods is a fundamentally flawed political approach.
Amendment proposals demonstrate that this does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or alternatively, balanced and unbalanced diets.
should our approach be.
The causes of inadequate nutrition are multifaceted.
To rectify this by attempting to guide consumers through product labels or even resorting to advertising bans or regulations, or by implementing different VAT rates, will not lead us to our goal.

I believe everything we do here doesn't want to preempt the labeling regulation debate, but everything we do should stand under a certain heading: what can we do to motivate consumers to reflect on their eating habits?

A traffic light labeling system that suggests to him that he is now facing a good or bad product, in my estimation, is more an instrument of socialization than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
Therefore, I desire a balanced approach here and the recognition that we will not be advanced by the path of product policy alone. Many thanks, Senior Krammer.
Mr. President, Madam Vice-President, esteemed colleagues! The budgetary control has no new topics.
We are satisfied with the old [ways/methods] and would also be satisfied with progress on the old [topics/issues].
Five points, first and foremost, our pressing request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in establishing the rule of law, judicial systems, and financial oversight.
We do not want to be where we are today in two years' time. Therefore, this point is very, very important to us.
The second point concerns the reliability statement for the overall budget according to the tiered control procedure, involving the national audit offices.
It would be desirable if we could achieve decisive progress here in the last six months that the Commission has remaining, or at the very least agree on a common path.
One learns to be modest as a budget controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We must provide greater assistance to the lower administrative levels of Member States in the implementation of EU law.
It is evident that they are completely overwhelmed by large portions of EU law. This explains the high error rates.
Fourth point: external assistance. Here, I would particularly like to address Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been in Kosovo, and I would now like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the discharge procedure.
I believe that we have remained far below the possibilities of the European Union to date, and that we urgently need to work further on this.
The fifth point would be the improvement of cooperation among member states in combating fraud.
Here, we have homework primarily for the members of the council.
Parliament will vote on the legal basis for the anti-fraud regulation in November. Then, we must jointly consider how to proceed if we wish to achieve better results in this area.
was, at least until now, our shared wish game.
Mr. President! India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, particularly also at the level of so-called ordinary people.
for business travelers, tourists, students, and so on, a brief note on this: she also has significance regarding the Commission’s legislative program, about which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic, we need good safety regulations—regulations that achieve something, and not mere alibi measures.
It would therefore be a sensible, genuinely necessary measure, finally to abolish the pointless liquid regulations and to come up with something worthwhile.
I voted in favor of the resolution because it is a clear call to the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled by the questionable, indeed fraudulent, parliamentary elections of September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of opposition as well as civil society.
Simultaneously, we have today urged the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Reduction of visa fees for Belarusian citizens, in consideration of their entry into the Schengen Area, and thereby preventing an increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
I would like to register my strongest objection, first and foremost, against the sentiment expressed just moments ago—that foreigners would inundate our labor market.
Secondly, I would have preferred a clearer, more definitive report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the European Union’s capacity for social cohesion can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States, and the Court of Justice of the European Union and not be satisfied with merely demanding a balance between fundamental rights and internal market freedoms, and the free movement of goods, services, capital, and persons.
That does not change anything. Social basic rights, just like freedom rights, are human rights that must not be restricted by flexibilities of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU Treaties.
It is time to amend the Posted Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements may not be limited as minimum requirements. Thank you.
Mr. President! I would like to join the thanks to the rapporteur, Doris Ba, which have already been quite rightly expressed by many colleagues.
We have with her someone who, hopefully, will not forget the passion, but who has invested a great deal of passion in this space.
I share your and your colleagues’ pleasure that progress has been made, also in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on the ground can also function within reasonable parameters.

However, I still believe that we must repeatedly point out to our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that they themselves, from their side, must contribute considerably more, perhaps even more than is currently being contributed in certain areas.
Internal collaboration, the willingness to engage in this internal work within the Ethni, is something we must consistently demand.
It is not a matter of everyone attempting to forge their own path.
And integration into the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is also important.
Madam President! The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not grow as vast as it has.
We need to ensure it is reduced in size.
In this context, the citizens' representative has an important role to play, especially when and where they perform it effectively.
It is primarily also about expecting engagement and judiciousness from the citizens’ representative.
It is about ensuring that we do not raise expectations that no one can subsequently meet.

It is also, on the other hand, about ensuring that wherever irregularities have occurred within the administrative bodies of the European Union, they are addressed and, wherever possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can assure and satisfy citizens.
Past practice has demonstrated that the citizen's representative undertakes this task seriously and effectively.
We can only hope that this remains the case. And we thank you and the rapporteur for this report.

Colleagues, ten years after the realization of the monetary union, Europe finds itself in a severe crisis.
Banks collapse or are propped up with billions from the state budget. Sales slump, and millions of people fear for their jobs and their future.
But not only has the market failed, also the prevailing politics seem incapable of learning from their mistakes.

We are also of the opinion, even with such asides, that you do not wish to unduly distinguish yourself. We are of the opinion that grave errors were committed in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
Such an error is the structural divergence of money and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing taxation and expenditure policy at least to some degree.
I believe the economic imbalances within the Eurozone have intensified considerably.
What we need now is, in fact, better coordination of economic and, above all, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping; furthermore, tax havens must be closed and capital flows finally controlled again.
We see the second serious error in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who believes that household consolidation is indispensable in times like these clearly lives in a different world. Nothing would be more fatal than responding to this economic crisis with public austerity programs as well.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our view, an investment offensive is necessary, to renew public infrastructure and to improve the situation of those socially disadvantaged in Europe.
A third error lies in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for the democratic control of the European Central Bank, and furthermore, we demand a correction of the ECB’s monetary policy mandate, ensuring that in the future, growth and employment are promoted at least equally with price stability.
The present crisis also offers an opportunity for far-reaching reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Council, esteemed colleagues! Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has further accelerated the crisis in this sector, and work is currently underway in the Member States to find solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key sector.
Therefore, we need European solutions for this key European industry to manage the crisis.
Almost all automotive corporations have European structures.

To enable necessary investments in environmental protection measures, as has been mentioned several times today, and to implement environmentally friendly and resource-efficient technologies, automakers require public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supplier industry, too, must not be overlooked in this regard.
Particularly in the supplier industry, it is small and medium-sized enterprises where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the previous plenary session, the President of the Council made a proposal to protect key industries.
a good proposal, as I see it, if one consistently pursues this thought to its conclusion, it would be a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
That would certainly be a useful instrument.
But this protective instrument is currently being challenged by the European Commission.
My question to the Commission: Will the European Commission maintain its commitment to a lawsuit despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or will it now change course in light of the crisis?
Dear Mr. President, Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors, and Vice-President of the European Commission, esteemed colleagues! Indeed, it has become tradition to observe.
We must acknowledge that, in relation to expenditure at the European level and administration at the national level, a declaration of assurance cannot repeatedly be issued.

I recall conversations with the former President of the Federal Audit Office, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, on account of the structures, it is simply not possible to issue a reliability declaration.
Therefore, we should consider together how this instrument can also be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a declaration of reliability, if justified, can also be achieved.
And here, we naturally need to distinguish a few things from one another.
Firstly, a budget that includes approximately 95% subsidies is far more susceptible to fraud than a national budget or a regional or municipal budget.

A subsidy budget that is essentially managed by the Member States, who have demanded significantly more autonomy from us in the new funding period, because the criticism of the previous funding period was that it would be too centrally controlled.
That naturally also means that responsibility for the money must be assumed regionally and nationally.
I will briefly address a third thematic area.
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These, too, are things that are frequently lumped together.
I, too, am annoyed when EU funds are used to support things that are not strictly necessary.
That, however, was not fraud; it was wastefulness.

Therefore, those who bear responsibility for projects, particularly in the area of structural policy, have a responsibility towards the Member States to ensure that money is not wasted and that only projects are funded which genuinely create added value for the region.
Therefore, we should certainly also consider converting parts of structural policy to interest-free loans.
If you must repay member states, then promote only what you genuinely need. Thank you very much.
it is not only difficult for me to concur with this burgeoning self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to managing the financial market crisis.
It goes without saying that if Europe were to be a functioning democracy, one would first need to address the question of accountability and how all of this came to pass.
It is simply not true that all the problems we face, which resemble a tsunami, are governed by natural laws, but rather are man-made.
And amidst all the regulatory quota that has distinguished this Union, one wonders, why was no action taken when banks began to cross national borders to a significant extent?
Why was no action taken despite corresponding warnings as the derivatives infiltrated?
I distinctly remember that Nobel laureate Josef Stiglitz addressed all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That is where one must begin, because recognizing one's own mistakes is, in itself, the key to finding solutions in the future.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! Commissioner! My question concerns your opinion on the introduction of the euro as a second currency in Iceland and Hungary.
Do you believe that this could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is: Do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which could then be used to strengthen the banks' equity?
My third question is: Don't you believe that a reduction in value-added tax would accordingly support imports, particularly from China and India?
Wouldn't it be more sensible to consider tax reductions for our businesses and for our employees to pay investment premiums, and to adjust the progressive depreciation accordingly into the

reintroduces and that, above all, low-value assets are increased by a factor of 10, so that no fictitious profits are taxed, the money remains within the enterprises, and, consequently, wages can also be paid better.
Madam President! The comprehensive report highlights how many human rights violations occur around the world every day.
This is particularly alarming 60 years after the proclamation of the Charter of Human Rights and calls on us to intensify our efforts.
For this reason, I would also like to advocate for the establishment of the current Sub-Committee on Human Rights as the main committee.
Today, we awarded the Sacharow Prize to Hojia, who advocates for human rights and the environment in China.
Because he is currently incarcerated, he was unable to take possession of it personally.
Shame for China! And tomorrow, a debate on human rights violations in Russia will take place here.
In our relations with these two countries, we must accord not only economic interests, but above all human rights a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hodjia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr. President, esteemed members of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! As rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one makes interesting observations, such as the fact that everyone talks about anti-fraud measures, and then nobody does anything.
Or the experience of member states calculating their payments to the European Union with a sharp pencil, but pulling out the generous trousers when it comes to spending that money.
and even make it easy for fraudsters, for example, because it still takes an average of 36 months before irregularities are reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament disagrees with this.
We want an efficient fraud prevention system that also includes preventative measures.
We want the member states to make fraud prevention a priority and that we discuss together the necessities and challenges involved.
We aim to foster greater interest among national judicial authorities in the subsequent prosecution of OLA mediation outcomes.
In the case of assessments, there must no longer be legal loopholes as there have been previously.
We need equalization of European money with national money.
We desire an independent office that possesses the necessary resources and legal foundations to fulfill its tasks.
We desire an office that can collaborate noiselessly and efficiently with the member states.
Our statement regarding the legal basis 17399 addresses all of these points.
We advocate for further developing this regulation as a core element of the Office for Anti-Fraud, together with the Council.

We request that the Council incorporate our observations.
We request that the Council begin discussions regarding the further development of this regulation.
We want to bring OLAF’s problems to a resolution.
I thank all factions of this House that you also support this, in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up and return the Parliament’s ball.
We have also incorporated solutions that the Council working group has developed and submitted in our proposals.
On our side, I am authorized to express our interest in a swift conclusion of this regulation and to assure you of our readiness for constructive discussions based on our proposals.
A consolidation of all OLAF legal bases, as the Council intended, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Ola will soon celebrate his tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
For us, combating fraud is simply too important.
We intend, therefore, that we undertake what is feasible now in collaboration with the Council.
Heartfelt thanks.
Mr. President! I would like to take up a remark that my Austrian colleague, Paul Rübig, mentioned earlier.

We invest less than 1 percent of European gross domestic product in Europe, and at the same time, we demand that an ever-increasing number of tasks for an ever-growing number of member states be managed by the European Union.
This calculation cannot be correct. It is therefore also truly implausible if we have been pursuing a savings course for many years, but this savings course is not only applied in the frugal
to utilize our funds, but fundamentally, to ensure that the finance ministers can reclaim money at the end of the year and channel it back into their own budgets.
We have enough new tasks for which we should be spending our money.
We also have tasks that have not been adequately funded for years.
I believe that the European Union’s information funding needs to be significantly increased if we genuinely want to connect European citizens with Europe.
There are numerous tasks in the area of student and trainee exchange where Europe could become involved.
also advancing into a previously traditionally state-reserved area within the justice sector.
This corresponds to the altered living conditions of the people in our Union.
But this observation has been made several times. Integration must not intrude too deeply into traditionally established structures, and especially not into those that are functioning well.
Not everything can be thrown at someone.
Public documents and public officials are structured quite differently in many Member States.
In Austria, but not exclusively in our country, the notary’s office has a long tradition as a public instrument of proof and enjoys a high level of security and trust.
This must not be jeopardized unnecessarily, simply because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual opening, yes, but with moderation.
Thank you, Madam President, esteemed colleagues! Plant protection products were and remain essential operating resources in the agricultural sector.
Farmers require a minimum selection of plant protection products, as this concerns the protection of the native cultural landscape, high-quality nutrition, and the safeguarding of resources.
We discuss chemicals far too often on a very irrational level.
To obtain sensible results, however, we must think and act rationally.
The consequences of the original parliamentary position – a broad ban on pesticides – would have been fatal, resulting in lower yields in agriculture and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am pleased that a barely acceptable compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is commendable that we have maintained the three-zone arrangements, albeit with significant exceptions for the Member States.

A courageous step toward a consistent internal market solution would look different. Beyond the acceptable compromises, we should refrain from prematurely defining endocrine-disrupting substances, but rather give the EU Commission the full four years to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be overextending the precautionary principle at this point.
Finally, I find it regrettable that we have not managed to initiate a follow-up assessment of the agreement reached at this time. Thank you very much.
Mr. When, during the last visit of a head of government or head of state, corresponding expressions of opinion occurred, the President of this House intervened massively.
At that time, it concerned a matter that was itself important to him, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When today the President, the sovereignly elected President of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted by the socialist side, is disturbed, the President does not intervene.
Do you know what this is?
That is not democracy; that is arbitrary rule, and I call for appropriate measures to be taken.
Minutes Children and politics rarely diverge so significantly between the interests of citizens and politicians.
For citizens across Europe, the issue of children is of paramount importance.
For politicians, children's concerns rank among distant considerations, as we can ascertain once again here.
I know of no country that has its own ministry for children. Nor does the commission have a dedicated representative for the interests of our youngest citizens.
In Parliament, the topic of childhood is scattered across all committees.
Therefore, I would like to particularly highlight to the Commission at this point that it is addressing childcare facilities and, in Barcelona, the issue of accommodation today.
! In our parliamentary working group on Quality of Childhood, we have ascertained the following: Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now, and today is entirely uncertain.
A child of today can climb to the very top of the social scale or fall further down.
It can remain within its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
It can follow a similar life path as its parents or do exactly the opposite.
One may marry someone of the opposite or same gender.
All of that was more than 50 years ago, when we founded the association Europa and everything was quite different.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans—this diversity has become a defining factor in children’s lives.
The concept of diversity must therefore be integrated into the pedagogy of childcare providers and teachers.
This is currently still far too little considered.
Europe’s childcare facilities and schools are struggling with the challenge of integration.
In integration matters, we must press the reset button back to the start.
Let us approach this topic once again completely free of prejudice, in accordance with the motto "Unity through Diversity."

Furthermore, I ask all my fellow Members of the European Parliament following me to not only advocate for gender mainstreaming. 
Also advocate for child mainstreaming, especially now during this time of the global financial crisis, because otherwise we will burden our children with immeasurable debt.
Thank you very much!
Mr. President, I will keep this very brief.
I am very grateful for these constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would like to transmit just two messages in conclusion. Firstly, I would like to express my explicit gratitude to the Commissioner for not having fundamentally opposed the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net.
This proposal is neither a devilish contraption nor a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving tool to which we should give an opportunity.
Therefore, I would like to advocate for it once again at this point.
and the second thing I'd like to say, and this is directed at my British friends, is cross all the parties.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline, I do understand your problem.
I can readily understand that, for a certain period, a country might prioritize energy security over adherence to an emission limit value.
I have considerable understanding of that.
I am also the last person who would deny Your Majesty any additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it, can’t we?
The problem is, we didn't do precisely that.
This conversation has never taken place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you to remain open-minded regarding the outlook in the second reading at this stage, and to say let us discuss a compromise at that point.
for that to relinquish the fundamentally oppositional resistance, which, from my perspective, is entirely irrational from a competition policy and environmental policy standpoint.
I believe this is the point where a compromise can be reached, one that I hope will also be achieved in the second reading at the end.
Incidentally, I do not believe that we should refrain from seeking compromise in the first reading.
For this, the legislation is too complex.
I do not wish to conclude this legislative term as rapporteur and leave a piece of legislation to the next parliament involving a text that is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
Therefore, I request your support for the compromises when we vote here in an hour. Thank you very much.

Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I believe the decisive question regarding all the economic stimulus programs currently being implemented across Europe is, of course, who ultimately receives the money?
We will issue banks further blank checks, although the rapid nationalization would ultimately be significantly cheaper for the taxpayer.
And should corporations and high-income earners be further relieved of their tax burden, despite having already benefited from tax breaks across Europe for years?

The more money is squandered for such purposes, the more predictable the failure of these programs becomes, and the more likely it is that the European economy will sink further and further into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, and liberalization—precisely this policy—has increasingly concentrated incomes among the top 10,000, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
Who believes that they can overcome this crisis by continuing precisely this policy with minor modifications? I think that person simply doesn't understand anything at all.
The precise opposite is required.
Instead of purchasing toxic assets from banks, tax funds should be used for the renovation of schools, hospitals, and for the ecological restructuring of the European economy.

If private companies receive public funding, it must be stipulated that no taxpayer money be provided without employment guarantees, and above all, no taxpayer money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, importantly, the general public can participate in future revenues.
The very best economic stimulus program that exists at present would be a radical redistribution of income and assets from top to bottom.
The sector reliant on hunger wages in Europe must be curtailed, rather than further promoted.
We need higher minimum wages, and we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that millionaires and the profiteers of the past financial market party now bear the immense losses that have arisen, and not the vast majority of citizens who, after all, never benefited from the entire financial boom.
I believe that what is socially just is currently also the economically most sensible.
It is the only way to discuss the devastating crisis dynamics.

Mr. President! At the beginning of March, the political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Tula Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be indicted again on untenable charges.
The first day of public hearings has been scheduled for March 31.
On the same day, human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were scheduled to take place.
These important discussions have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia thereby demonstrates very clearly the low priority it assigns to human rights.
The judiciary will continue not only to fail to deliver justice, but to be employed for the persecution of regime opponents, thereby undermining the EU.
Sir, Commissioner, many thanks, dear colleagues! I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again addressing the prohibition of animal testing.

has pointed out, because it reminds me that this is now the third amendment to cosmetics legislation that I have been privileged to accompany – the fourth amendment, the fifth amendment, and now the amendment to a regulation.
And we have, in fact, managed to prohibit animal testing.
We have managed to ensure that, for example, consumers know how long a product remains shelf-stable by seeing a small container with a number indicating its remaining validity period.

I am also addressing this to some colleagues, particularly my colleague Reuteko Reutova, who unfortunately could not be present at the beginning. Markings are never warnings at any time. If a product is not safe, it must not be on the market, it must not be marketed.
Every product present in this European market must be safe and without risk.
But the labeling gives consumers the opportunity to choose.
That is democracy, and that is its freedom of choice.
I believe it would be very good legislation.
I have endeavored to design the procedure in a very transparent manner.
I have attempted, as Ms. Crostet also stated, to bring together different viewpoints.

For I am concerned that we create legislation that is good legislation for all—for the consumers of the European Union, for the industry that must work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who will benefit from it.
Colleague Stellhard, I say again, yes, the DO affects everyone differently, but the statement keeps them sweat-free. We still did it.
Therefore, it is important that the statements regarding my fold depth around the eyes are also reasonably realistic and reliable after one week in Strasbourg.
I would like to extend my thanks once more to the Commissioner, also regarding the explanations he provided to my colleagues and to my staff, who did the majority of the work.
Thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! The report by Mr. Vanisterol concerning the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most significant of the Committee on Regions in recent years.
We agree with the fundamental concept of the Green Paper, according to which territorial cohesion is essentially about the policentric development of the
overall, to ensure sustainable development of the jurisdictions with diverse characteristics and specific features, while simultaneously preserving their diversity.
It is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of graduated assistance for transition regions exceeding the threshold of 75
must be created so that these regions receive a distinct status and thus have greater security in their development.
In the report by Ms. Krehe on obstacles to the drawdown of Structural Funds, the most significant deficiencies faced by applicants in the
Accessing structural funds is hindered by factors such as excessive administrative burden, too many complex regulations, and slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the member states.
Various recommendations are made to the Commission regarding the implementation of effective measures to reduce these obstacles.
I would like to single out and reiterate two such measures.
First and foremost, project managers must retain their project documentation for a period of ten years, to have it readily available for audits, which are also conducted by the Commission.
Especially for smaller projects, the excessively bureaucratic effort is problematic.
Indeed, that is now to be reduced to a period of three years. And secondly, the EU Commission’s assessment criteria for innovative projects present considerable difficulties.
In innovative projects, the same evaluation criteria should not be used as for other projects.
It is simply necessary that something different occurs here.

Madam President! When Europe puts money on the table, and when, above all, the member states put a great deal of money on the table to help the automotive industries in their crisis situation, then it cannot be about merely securing the existence and maintaining the status quo to prevent change, but about a range of other concerns.
The most important ones have been named.
It is about enabling people to seek employment, and ensuring that employment as well, and that on a long-term basis.
To achieve this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and, above all, sustainability within the transport system more strongly than we have done previously.

Therefore, we should link all our measures to these objectives, so that we are not subjected to the criticism in a few years’ time. We should have thought of all this many years ago; then we would not be facing the next and new crisis.
Thank you, Madam President! It would be kind if you would also grant me the additional half-minute that my Green colleague, Ms. Breyer, has just received.
The Commission has presented a good proposal for updating the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some proposed amendments seek to supplement this proposal with stipulations that are incompatible with the objectives of the regulation or even intend to intervene in existing jurisprudence.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with regard to the health and welfare of animals would simply overwhelm the retailers.
Once again, there is an attempt to undermine existing GMO laws, specifically the demand for special labeling of novel foods derived from animals fed with genetically modified feed.
We have just heard it. I think.
Generally, everything pertaining to GMO legislation should not be addressed within the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this, although I myself, for example, have submitted a proposal to specifically delineate new plant-based products from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be the case that interested parties within this institution are abusing the Nobel Food Regulation for campaign purposes.
This appears to be the kind of attempt also represented by amendment proposals 62 and 90, for which the Greens have requested a roll-call vote.
Which valued colleagues do you intend to expose with that?
My faction has always advocated for the consumer’s right to know what is contained in foodstuffs.
Why shouldn’t one therefore indicate a nano origin on the ingredient declaration?
And although Amendment 62 rather clumsily attempts to anticipate my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling by Noble Food to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend to my faction that they approve of the aforementioned motions and will include in my report on the food labelling regulation references to the part of the Novel Food Regulation that deals with labelling.
That is possible because we postponed the first reading on footlabeling to the next legislative term, against the wishes of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement proved to be.
Briefly regarding cloning, it is animal cruelty.
We are opposed.
Nevertheless, foodstuffs must be included in this regulation accordingly, otherwise a legal void would result.
Madam President, that is quite simple.
Whoever does not want this man to chair the formal opening session of the European Parliament should support my proposal to amend the rules of procedure.!

Madam President, Madam President, dear Commissioner, esteemed colleagues!

One thing I would like to state clearly at the outset: the provision of food to those in need, particularly in these economically challenging times, is not open for debate in the upcoming vote on our colleague Tschikerski’s report.
Therefore, I also want to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common line within our parliamentary group.
I therefore respect the personal decision of each colleague in our group to deviate and not to agree with the rejection of the report that we have planned.
Why can I not agree with the outcome of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this, none of which, absolutely none, have to do with assisting those in need within the European Union during these economically challenging times.

On the contrary, the amendment proposals submitted by my colleagues Nils Busk on behalf of ArtEFktion, but regrettably deemed inadmissible, were intended to establish the existing system on a sustainable basis.

Intelligent transport systems based on EU-wide, binding, and fundamental quality standards and regulations improve the environment for innovation and create planning certainty, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.

We know too little about the willingness and ability of potential users to pay.

Mr. President! For the first time since I have been a member of this assembly, I voted against the discharge of the Commission in the vote on the discharge, and I would like to
My primary concern in outlining my reasons is the manner in which the European Commission handled the accessions of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high level of corruption, with a great deal of money, with a great deal of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only began freezing these funds in 2008.
We lost a significant amount of money in 2007, and we are now dealing with either a virtually nonexistent control system or one that functions only sporadically.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high rate of corruption and problems within the judiciary.
All of this is attributable to the pre-accession process.

My aim is to set a precedent, to tell the European Commission as well that it must proceed differently for future accessions, and to tell it that, as has already been observed in other countries, it could certainly be more successful if it wishes to do so.
I would like to urge the Commission to assist the two countries in establishing financial control systems that merit the name and help eliminate systemic weaknesses in those two countries.
Otherwise, we will have a persistent problem and a constant cause for concern hanging around Europe’s neck. Thank you.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! A microfinance instrument for the unemployed, for those threatened by unemployment, and especially for people who do not have access to normal credit markets, is a good intention and is supported in principle by our parliamentary group.
However, what the Commission and Council have achieved in terms of performance in this process is simply inadequate, partially incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
First point of criticism: the question of financial resources.
What is presented as financial support here is not financial support for an unemployment reduction program. It cannot be termed a microfinance program. At best, it could be described as nanofinance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to performing such sleight of hand without any effect, which comes at the expense of other programs and thereby dissipates endlessly.
Thirdly, the conception of the sustainability and success of such a program must incorporate organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new startups, particularly in the microfinance sector, fail. Therefore, provisions must also be made within the program to address this.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the Member States are not withdrawn for the purpose of accessing this program; otherwise, it will be ineffective.
That cannot sustainably combat unemployment.
We will reject it in this form.

Mr. President! The current debate is a central debate about the character of the European Union.

Mr. President! Regional structural promotion is an essential instrument in European integration, and in particular, Objective 2 funding has in the past been perceived by people in many regions as a driver of local structural and economic development.
It is an important element for managing structural change in regions and municipalities.
Here, Europe is also tangibly experienced by citizens because it also has an effect on location.
However, we need simpler, clearer, and more transparent structures within the Cohesion Funds and improved controls to ensure that the resources are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the convergence in social and economic development, is a primary objective within the EU, and therefore we must not weaken these instruments in the future, but rather strengthen them.
Cohesion policy in Europe requires greater clarity, increased transparency, efficiency, and also the individual member states' accountability.
Therefore, it is important to adhere to the system of additive funding.
We do not, however, want a renationalization of structural support.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to ensure that the funding criteria meet these requirements from 2013 onwards.

It seems to me, both for us, for the EU in general, but also for this Parliament in particular, that it is somewhat symptomatic that we reflexively conduct discussions about situations in countries whose situation is not new.
It is unfortunate that after-effects frequently lead to us suddenly and in waves spilling forth into political forums, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe it is not becoming of us to initiate a general debate about Yemen solely on the basis of a failed airplane attack.
I believe that we should be clear with ourselves that it behooves us to consider a strategy for dealing with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a thorough analysis, namely that it constitutes a failed state, within which a government operates that no longer controls large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks arise from this for Europe.
The risks appear to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is evidently taking place.
Therefore, I believe it is up to us, and perhaps also to Ms. Ashton, to consider what we can do against these risks.
For my part, the question can primarily be: How can we bolster the government in Yemen, regain control of the country, and contain these risks?

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country, of course, must also take place. But I don’t believe it’s truly sensible, or that we will be taken seriously, if we now initiate a catalog of demands covering all policy areas—from media freedom to the rights of women here in Parliament.

I believe that will not achieve the desired outcome in Yemen, but rather we should focus on what specific assistance we can provide in the current situation to resolve an acute problem. Thank you very much.

Policy coherence for development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

It makes little sense, for example, to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries when, at the same time, we destroy local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
Equally, we can strive as much as we like for better healthcare if we obstruct the use of generics or, through patent extensions, drive medication prices to unaffordable levels.

And while biofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU to a limited extent, they lead to deforestation and land conversion in developing countries, thereby exacerbating climate change—precisely what we are trying to avoid—not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and reduction in arable land for food production.
Currently, we—that is, the EU as such—are not particularly coherent.
That political measures should not contradict each other has long been recognized by the EU in theory.
The Treaty of Lisbon enshrines policy coherence for development.
Article 208 states: When implementing political measures that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take into account the objectives of development cooperation.
We must be prepared to meet this demand.
This year, we are reviewing progress toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear: without political coherence, we will not succeed in fulfilling our promises.

We must become aware of this responsibility, as must all those who enact and implement laws. Before we decide on a measure, there must be a consequence assessment, so that we can even recognize what effects of European legislation could have negative impacts on developing countries.
We need expertise in advisory bodies, commissions, and parliament that recognizes inconsistencies.
The Commission's policy coherence programme is a good step in this regard.
Now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Political coherence in the interest of development means that in the fisheries reform, we must give greater consideration to the interests of local people and must not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing conglomerates.
It means that we must stem the outflow of funds from developing countries to tax havens.
It means that we cannot agree to ACTA if the suspicion remains that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
Thus far, the Commission has been unable to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that when establishing the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the responsibilities of the development commissioner must be expanded, not restricted.
And it is also important that we, for example, enable Fair Trade products in the awarding of contracts in municipalities, as my colleague Heide Rüle has suggested.
In many cases, we must carefully monitor Members of the Commission and the Council to ensure that they shape policy coherently.
In many cases, it also rests with us, the members of parliament, to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to better coordinate between the committees, and we require either one or a permanent rapporteur.
The report, unanimously adopted by the Development Committee, contains many good suggestions and brings us a significant step forward.
I would like to thank all shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman, and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the full assembly tomorrow.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues! For months, we have been discussing the matter of driving times and working hours in road transport.
I wonder what arguments will now be deployed to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is nonsense.
The most recent argument is that we urgently need to change something so that nothing changes.
Do you not notice, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argumentation has become, how riddled it is with lies and half-truths?
This dispute concerns nothing other than an extension of working hours for self-employed individuals.
In labor law, the fundamental question for 150 years has been the protection of people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both self-employed individuals and salaried employees.
It makes no difference whether one is a freelancer feeling overwhelmed or whether an employer is overwhelming an employee driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessive working hours, in part also from employers and clients.
Secondly, regarding road traffic safety, it is asserted here that nothing can possibly happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in a hobby hardware store, and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws with the motto “Let’s see what comes of it.”
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours are conducive to accidents, particularly in road traffic, with serious consequences.
Third point: Who, then, should control a more detailed regulation, as you envision it, in the future on our roads?
Today, a state labor judge cannot verify whether someone appears self-employed or is genuinely self-employed without an extensive review of records.
Let this nonsense go—it’s about fair competition.
It is not a matter of setting a precedent today for future negotiations regarding the extension of working hours.
Do not play such games with this house. I thank you!

Madam President! As I have for many years now, today I am advocating for road safety, an improvement in the working conditions of our professional drivers, and the enhancement of their professional image.

Quite clearly, today we are not discussing the traffic safety regulations concerning driving and rest times, which all self-employed and employed professional drivers must adhere to; today, we are addressing working time regulation.
It is primarily a regulation to protect employees, and therefore serves only the social protection of drivers and in no way traffic safety.
We do not need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

Compliance with working hours is neither controllable with significant bureaucratic effort in the case of self-employed truck and bus drivers, nor is there a traceable reason for conducting such controls at all.

Restricting self-employed professional drivers, and in the future perhaps also self-employed tradespeople, architects, or members of parliament, in their permissible working hours sends the wrong signal.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues! Just a few days ago, we witnessed with dismay on television how vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries were flooded.
People have perished in the floodwaters, and our deepest sympathy goes to their families. Numerous towns, farmland, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been superseded by other images. The immense damage, however, must still be painstakingly removed.
In addressing damages of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the European Union’s member states.
Following the 1997 flood disaster, Poland and, this time, other Central European states are again affected by a flood catastrophe.
We cannot yet regulate the weather, and flooding is inherent to rivers at certain times.
But the questions we must ask are whether, in the knowledge that these natural events can always occur, the right preventative measures are being taken.
Were damaged by such natural events and whether, for example, in landscape planning, the questions of sustainable disaster prevention received due consideration.
When assistance is provided, it should initially benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster to ensure their survival.

Then, however, even in international cooperation, efforts to mitigate natural disasters should no longer stop at state borders, and prevention of damage caused by natural disasters should be coordinated by the member states at the European level.

That jointly implemented preventative measures can offer protection is demonstrated by the flood protection along the Oder River, which has been jointly developed there to date by Polish and German authorities.
But we are not at the end yet.
We do not, however, require European civil protection.
The protection of its country from disasters should be the principal task of a nation’s government, which should also include the development of disaster plans.

But coordination of assistance in the event of damage or incidents should also benefit from efficient European coordination, and those organizations that provide rapid and non-bureaucratic assistance on a voluntary basis should not be left to bear their costs.
Therefore, I support the plans of the Commissioner, Ms. Georgieeva, that we proceed swiftly.

I believe the citizen, given the enormous tax burden they have been subjected to as a result of this crisis, expects swift, decisive, and well-reasoned action here.
Citizens are little interested when power plays are enacted at the national level, where the sole issue is who decides.
What the citizen desires is effective decision-making, the resolution of problems.

Objectively, it is the case that in emergency situations concerning measures, these must be centrally regulated and decided upon at the European level when coordination between member states is insufficient and does not function.
Unfortunately, not on the line of decisions made by the G20, the G8 of heads of state and government, not at the level of the Council.
The council makes him small, small, a small square.
This is not an acceptable policy for citizens.
We expect the Council to act. Thank you.

Gentlemen Commissioners, dear colleagues, ladies and gentlemen! One sometimes wonders what we have actually been doing for over a year now, with all the discussions and debates, the many sessions in the trilogue, where I could have envisioned spending my time in a more agreeable way.

At this point, over a year after the European elections, where we proclaimed on the streets and squares how we intended to rein in the financial markets, we are actually faced with a very meager, if not nonexistent, result.
The problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that operate globally today.
Member States still believe that they are capable of enforcing rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely the fact that this did not work also did not trigger the financial crisis with a single contribution, but did contribute to the fact that it affected Europe as well.

Therefore, the question arises for me, at what point this realization, frequently articulated in Sunday speeches, will be translated into political action, where it suddenly concerns protecting stock exchange locations, where it concerns protecting banking structures, and no longer protecting the citizens.

As the European Parliament, we have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also dedicate themselves to it, for they bear joint responsibility for the citizens to implement proper supervisory rules that ensure the individual’s savings remain permanently secure.

Naturally, gentlemen commissioners, I would certainly wish that everything possible is now being done on the part of the Commission to ensure we arrive at a favorable outcome as swiftly as possible in the interest of the people of Europe.
Colleagues, ladies and gentlemen! We stand in this European Parliament with the responsibility for a robust regulation of financial markets.
All of what we had proposed was significantly diluted in the trilogues.
The government and administration do not desire extensive interventionist powers.
Giegold is correct to describe what is currently happening as parochial thinking.
Not poor regulation, but rather to construct the system a little more fault-free, seems to be the intention.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will be unable to exercise genuine control over financial markets.
From this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, inadequate consequences are drawn, and thus the next crisis is already prepared.
Many economists, even in Europe, will not survive the next blows, with all the social and economic consequences for the people of Europe.
You expect this predatory financial market capitalism to be recaptured and the primacy of politics restored.
When the CEO of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, stated over the weekend, "We need a strong and unified European financial supervision and a common rule for
Member states are advocating for stricter capital rules, which is an appeal to this Parliament to truly establish those rules.
It is incumbent upon this European Parliament to exert pressure on the Council to urgently implement effective regulation. This would be merely the first step towards a status quo.
Let concrete actions follow those bold promises at last. My group stands for robust European regulation.
Anything short of regulation would be a danger to the euro, to a common EU, and to democracy. Thank you.

But to the point, Commissioner, you are giving the correct signal. Commissioner, Mr. President, we will finalize today or, more precisely, tomorrow, a legislative package that we have been discussing for more than two years.
This is not only due to the controversial liability, but also to an interim European election and the entry into force of a new EU treaty, which has led to us having to adjust certain aspects.

But I believe that if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we should now vote on a compromise, one which is certainly worth affirming, even if one may perhaps do so with a clenched fist in one's pocket.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One pertains to the environmental requirements for industrial facilities.
The objective here is to ensure that the best available technology in Europe is more effectively implemented.
I believe that we have found an exception clause in the current compromise that gives the EU Commission, in the Pototschnik case and quite clearly addressed to them, the instrument.

to pay closer and greater attention in the coming years than previously to ensuring that the approximately 52,000 industrial facilities affected in Europe ultimately utilize best available techniques more effectively than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
I would like to address and reflect this as well, because I simply cannot understand it.
We are often told that the use of best available techniques is too expensive, and that this further jeopardizes the competitiveness of European industry, especially during times of crisis.
I do not enjoy recalling my past, but I am from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also attributable to having missed, over decades, investment in the latest technology.

I believe that every industry, every industrial enterprise, is obligated by its very existence to invest in the state of the art, because otherwise it loses competitiveness and, incidentally, reduces pollutant emissions.
we believe we have the opportunity today to enact a law that improves this situation.
The second part of the directive—and this is, to some extent, the concentrated fist I mentioned—concerns macro-control systems.

We are once again discussing the fact that in the most recent directive, we granted repeated exemptions until 2020, and in some cases until 2023, for large combustion plants that do not need to meet environmental requirements, specifically air pollutant emission limits.
I am addressing here the addressee to the council, perhaps also a little to all of us, that we must very carefully consider how sensible this actually is, that we regularly
Ambitious environmental goals are welcomed and discussion of them is here embraced, but whenever it comes to implementing them, to codify them into concrete legislation, a tragedy begins in Europe.
Then, member states suddenly realize what it costs, what bills they have to pay, and typically, those who have made advance contributions are penalized as a result.
There is, in fact, a number of member states that already meet the requirements today and which will ultimately be left standing in the rain.
And I say it again here, both with industrial plants and with large-scale control systems, we are essentially talking about coal-fired power plants; we are not discussing science fiction.
We are not discussing things that are not available, but rather the state of the art.
the available techniques—what is available on the market under competitive and cost-related aspects—can be integrated into these systems, and against this background, we conclude
introduce a legislative package, which I believe is better than what is currently in effect, and therefore I urge us all to approve it.

I would also like to thank my colleagues who, at times, have been deeply involved over the past two years, for their support, their contributions, and above all, for the fact that nearly all key factions have co-signed this compromise.

Three things have happened – we have debated. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become football world champion.
A good omen, I believe.
Who precisely will become, will a few see?
would not express any preferences.
Secondly, Germany is receiving compliments from the UK.
Many thanks don’t happen every day.
It is worth noting that.
And thirdly, the world is still in order; even among the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Wasikut is gone again.
Heartfelt congratulations, of course, to our Icelandic friends.
Two aspects I wished to contribute to the debate, which I have just been following.
Firstly, I understand all the concerns and hardships of my Eastern European friends only too well.
I am, as someone from East Germany, also half Eastern European.
I understand that not every environmental policy step taken in Western European countries in recent decades can immediately be replicated in Eastern Europe.
Environmental protection at a high level must be affordable.
Yes, that is correct.

But I believe that even taking this sentence into consideration, it is worthwhile to agree to this compromise clause, because it does justice to the diverse starting situations in which many member states find themselves.
And secondly, the argument that employing state-of-the-art techniques endangers competitiveness, particularly vis-à-vis China. This argument is not only false, it is even dangerous.
We must confront the fact that industrial processes in Asia are, without a doubt, cheaper than they are here.
We will only succeed in this competition, however, if we employ the best available technology across as many industrial sectors as possible.
Those who fail to do so lose competitiveness.
No one is demanding, not even this law, that an industrial operation be shut down tomorrow.
No one demands the leap from zero to one hundred to achieve any emission limit value within a week.
We have sufficient transitional periods, but to say that one should forgo them for competitive reasons is incorrect.
I believe that with this directive, we have not only set an environmental policy course, but I also believe we have made an industrial policy decision that merits effort in the coming years.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to begin, first of all, by thanking my colleagues from the other groups in the preparation of my report on Kosovo, including Ms. Eva Mar, who has done very valuable work at the Secretariat here.

I also wish to extend my thanks to you, Mr. Commissioner, for the good cooperation, but also to address what you mentioned, namely that it was important to you to travel to the north of Kosovo, even to spend a night there, and thereby to make it clear to the population that you stand for them as well.
delivered a speech at the university and inaugurated the EU House there.

I believe that was an important sign to make clear what this European Parliament has already expressed in the past and is expressing again now, namely its support for an independent Kosovo on its path to the European Union.
We are currently facing a situation in which Kosovo, and its citizens—particularly those of all ethnic groups—are once again at a critical juncture.
In a few weeks, the International Court will deliver its opinion on how to assess the declaration of independence from just over two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion will then be an opportunity—something like an open wind, as it’s called in English—to place regional cooperation on a new basis, but without relinquishing state sovereignty.

To clarify Kosovo’s origins and its independence, and to make clear that the shared future for all states in the region—for Serbia, for Kosovo, and for all others—lies in membership of the European Union, and that on the path to that membership, the problems that still exist must also be resolved.
It is also the text that the resolution makes clear that the future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

For the citizens of the country, especially the young, must not have the impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot go out, while everyone else in the surrounding area will soon have that future.

I have also submitted a new amendment proposal that places strong regret over the outbreaks of violence in recent days to the fore and expresses great hope for swift and independent clarification, without allowing it to serve as a basis for the escalation of emotions in the coming days and weeks.
Madam President, esteemed High Representative, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues! The recent events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people,
The burning of houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who abandoned their homes and tried to flee the violence. All of this has shaken me and evoked compassion for the victims.
Simultaneously, these events in Kyrgyzstan also shed light on the situation in Central Asia, which should not leave us untouched here in the European Parliament.
On the contrary, we should devote our full attention to the countries of this region.

In doing so, our focus should not be limited to states rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but rather encompass all states equally within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
That is, I, our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which gained their freedom from the formerly Tsarist and later Soviet dominion less than 20 years ago, bear a heavy legacy.
Arbitrarily drawn boundaries by Italy, disregarding the homelands of the peoples living there, evidently complicate coexistence both within and outside the borders of those states.
Poverty-related corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, and economic conditions, as exemplified in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, affect hundreds of thousands.

Labor immigration forces, and as is now being admitted in Kyrgyzstan, conflict resolution through the application of violence leaves the path of these states toward the future shrouded in question marks.
Here, we must not merely watch the European Union.
If we do not want to allow the path of these states to lead into fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to leave people there to permanent dictatorial regimes, it requires our full commitment.
Alongside the urgently needed material assistance, we require contact with these states and active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbayeva a chance in pacifying Kyrgyzstan and on the path to stable political conditions. Let us allow what is being debated here to be put to a vote tomorrow.

We also resolve to follow through with actions, so that the people of Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states feel that we will not leave them alone on their path to the future, nor deliver them to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of these countries towards us Europeans are high. We should not disappoint them.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner! I am very much in favor of green genetic engineering, but cloning—that is something else.
That simply cannot be compared to it.
Cloning is animal cruelty. And many colleagues have already stated this here.
I also presented this during the summer break in the discussion we had. Only a fraction of animal clones are actually viable.
and those that survive, of whom very, very many die, very early and in a very agonizing way.
suffer from malformations of extremities and organs
They have weakened immune systems; they are susceptible to illness.
That means pain and suffering, and precisely this agonizing death.
Can we possibly be responsible for that?
We advocate for animal welfare, and then we want to support such technology.
No, that is not what we want, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want any cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is only consistent.

Yes, we know that products from cloned animals or their descendants are unlikely to be detrimental to health, and I personally assume that they would in fact be suitable for human consumption. But there is, in fact, no shortage of meat from conventionally raised livestock.
Why should we engage with this clone?
It is quite unnecessary to engage in this animal cruelty. The population simply does not want it.
The population does not want these products, we don’t need them ourselves either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
Therefore, we want to establish a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and, indeed, for their offspring as well.
I want a ban on cloning and cloned products within the European Union, and I also believe that we can enforce it.
Naturally, I must also apply this to imports.
I want to be certain that I am not surreptitiously served cloned meat, because it is not labeled, as has already happened here.
Well, and I don't believe that all meat can be traced.
The beef market is possible.
However, with pork, due to the volume produced, it will not be possible to trace whether an animal ever had a clone in its lineage.
Fundamentally, yes, it is a matter of principle, it is an ethical question.
And colleagues have said it: we must also address ethical questions, and we are also responsible for ethical questions.
There is, of course, the question of animal welfare, but it is also another question.

Experience shows I am an animal producer and have studied it. Experience shows that all reproductive techniques, once they functioned effectively in animal production, were ultimately also applied to humans.
Therefore, we must ask ourselves today: Will and can we employ cloning technology in the foreseeable future? Can we also accept this in the case of humans?
I do not want that, and I cannot do that either.
And even if a replacement part clone could perhaps one day donate a vital organ, a clone of myself, then I would not want that.
I do not believe that to be an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that would be possible in not too dissimilar a future, if we were to permit cloning.
Therefore, we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloners and their descendants throughout the entire EU.
I have no fear of the WTO.
We can enforce that.
We do not need to emulate everything the USA dislikes, despite all transatlantic friendship.

Lisbon is not a purely technical change, but signifies more tasks, signifies fulfilling more tasks, and consequently, answering related financial questions.
Furthermore, the Council adopted resolutions that will result in new financial expenditures.
This has been carried out by many colleagues.

If the council desires this and if the council desires that no more money should be spent, then the council must also state where specifically it wants to cut back, how it wants to cut back, where it wants to reallocate funds precisely, and not just in general terms.

to propose percentage shifts and then leave it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide where the inconveniences fall, particularly since our possibilities for reallocation and changes to the budget are extremely limited.

Dear Commissioner Hahn, colleagues,

I have a problem with parts of the debate.

When we speak of mountain settlements and sparsely populated regions, I gain the impression from individual contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that is not the case.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state, which are sovereign.
The implementation of European resolutions and objectives remains the responsibility of the Member States in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

When I consider the European level, we have consistently focused particularly on these areas—mountainous regions, sparsely populated areas, islands—in Commission communications up to and including the Lisbon Treaty.
And here, too, in Parliament, many resolutions were passed to support this region.
When I hear so many complaints here now that grievances persist in these areas, the question arises for me: How have the member states dealt with the impetus we have sent from the European level?
And how have the regions themselves approached this and utilized European funding opportunities?

Here, a new strategy is being demanded. The officials of DGRego Lei, who are tasked with encompassing the multitude of problems of islands, mountains, and sparsely populated regions within a strategy, are already feeling the strain.

Simultaneously, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies—Danube, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, climate change, and similar matters—to the point that we will soon need a strategy for the strategies themselves, so that we can still maintain an overview.

Esteemed colleagues, putting aside the levity! I believe what it’s really about – and this has also been mentioned today – and for that I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for bringing it up. We must fight to ensure that there is a cohesion policy and a regional policy at the European level also after 2013.
That is the focus of our work, and it is in that regard that we should also convince our parliamentary colleagues that this will be the case.
As a continuation of cohesion and regional policy beyond 2013, mountains, islands, and other regions will also find their place.
However, we should not become bogged down in individual resolutions concerning a topic for which there is currently no occasion. Thank you very much.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues! Undeniably, we have made progress in recent years regarding gender equality. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are relegated to low-skilled employment.
This applies not only to activities traditionally performed within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, mandatory social security contributions have frequently been transformed into atypical, precarious, and insecure employment relationships.
There, particularly women.
European employment trends from 2000 to 2010 encompass 60 new precarious and atypical employment relationships, predominantly affecting two-thirds of them women.
Frequently, women are denied democratic participation due to their part-time employment or precarious employment in businesses.
Women are, however, significantly more engaged and better educated than in all previous generations.
You still earn 25 less than men on average.
We have engaged very intensively with this topic in the Employment Committee and developed good proposals for the question of female employment, irrespective of the status of their work.
Social security systems, the creation of childcare facilities, the alignment of pensions and social systems with independent living, and the design of work according to the principles of decent work.
All of this essentially concerns the precarious employment of women as addressed in the report.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the results of this work and requests approval for the submitted report.

Many—I want to emphasize this once more—many believed that the euro crisis had been over.
Ireland demonstrates that this was not the case.
Europe continues to voluntarily surrender itself to financial markets.
The member states of the EU must continue to pledge their sovereign debt on the market of financial actors and save themselves through self-destruction, in order to acquire the trust of speculators.
Over the weekend, we once again had to observe where that leads.

This time, it was not the Greeks, supposedly prone to all kinds of fraud, but model student Ireland that was driven into the European rescue funds to save its banking system, which had also long been considered exemplary, exemplarily deregulated.

The ECB bears a degree of responsibility for this drama.

While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB looks on impassively as the other half continues to sink further into poverty and insecurity.
The austerity measures of entire economies might appeal to European funds and bank circles. However, they have neither helped Ireland, nor the monetary union, nor the ECB.
