One has not taken the many appearances into account, it has been said. What does the patient need?
I believe it is correct that we have decided that the patient can inform himself in various ways and not just one.
But I would like to emphasize that the physician will continue to be the patient’s trusted confidant and will also certainly exert influence in crucial matters.
We guarantee this, because we have, in fact, prohibited the advertising for it, and the information the patient receives has been checked and approved by an authority.
With this, the information is substantiated scientifically, and the patient can confidently handle it as a result.
Naturally, it is correct, not everyone can investigate.
There are various ways to do that over the internet, and I believe it’s so widespread that we don’t need to worry about it.
I only hope that the council now finally has the courage to address this topic.
It is very important; it must be acted upon swiftly.
The patients expect that.
I believe we have then done a good piece of work, many!
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, dear colleagues! Coal is part of the energy supply. That is undeniable.
It is undeniable, too, that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization may not be the appropriate path.
The question now is whether the appointment with 214 or 218 is correct.
Colleague Rabke has presented a wealth of insightful arguments that I need not repeat.

My request to the Commission is essentially only this: Here, within the Parliament, there is evidently a large majority across all the committees involved who affirm that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that we simply establish the necessary flexibility in the matter of the timeline, which is essential to also create the possibility for the Member States to implement it, and that the burdens for people, for jobs, and for economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that has been raised – incidentally, also in contrast to the Commission’s assessment, which initially seemed inclined to express itself similarly for 2018 – was the argument that climate policy considerations could play a role here.
I want to emphasize this point once again: it makes no difference to the climate question whether one burns foreign coal or one’s own coal.

My request to the Commissioner is to reflect once more on whether this four-year period, should it arise in Parliament and if such a new line of argumentation arises in the Council, could not lead to the Commission also becoming somewhat more flexible.
I understood the remark just now to mean that the commission is giving this matter consideration, and I thank you for that.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner! If one is to draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, held the presidency, then it is this: that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.

We may, at various points, disagree on this.
But if, as Europeans, we already speak with divergent voices, then our influence will not be credible, and if we are not credible, then others will not follow us.
Why should you?

Therefore, it is correct that the figures we decided upon in the final year 2002 under Chancellor Merkel and 2007 under Chancellor Merkel must essentially remain in place and form the foundations of this negotiation.

I share your opinion that the ambitious 2-degree target should not be seriously questioned today in favor of a significantly lower degree, because doing so would make the feasibility of these goals extraordinarily difficult and would alienate the public.
I have a significant concern that we are challenging our intellectual property.
Also, our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we were to go now and loosen the fence around this intellectual property, leaving the holes as they currently are, then the valuable parts, namely our property, would simply walk away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a purpose in investing in it, and therefore intellectual property must not be diluted.
Regarding the obligation, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible, and they must be feasible for these countries.
Thus, we are doing precisely the opposite of what we intend, namely, you will distance yourselves from us.
Also, being credible in Cancun is an important point.
The really big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancun I believe we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, it will yield nothing with the harvest.
Let us focus on the good soil.
Mr. President, Mr. President! There was an incident during the speech at the European Council summit that I myself do not wish to address, as I was the target of an insult.

However, I want to say that there are levels at which I cannot be offended, and where I also do not perceive something as an insult, because to insult me, one must possess a certain degree of seriousness.
I would, however, like to express my sincere gratitude for the countless expressions of solidarity and thanks that I have received here in this house since then.
I would like to express my sincere thanks to you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I believe this is a sign of our shared, democratic, and pro-European conviction, which the overwhelming majority of this House shares.
For this, my heartfelt thanks.

Dear Commissioner, Dear Minister, Dear Mr. Gss, dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs!

I am delighted that we have now created this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is placed under European direct supervision.
This is also a step toward a strong Europe within a single market, for strong control over a sector that contributed to the crisis.
I should like to add a remark, dear Herr Vannierzeit, regarding the selection processes for the new authorities; and the new authorities are only as good as their personnel.

I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, genuine consideration will be given to expertise and independence from the financial industry they are meant to oversee, and to a clear commitment to public interests, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process, overriding these crucial criteria.
Furthermore, much remains to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still lack true transparency regarding the information used by rating agencies. There is far too much reliance on regulatory ratings within the financial sector and in regulations pertaining to the financial industry.
We have severe conflicts of interest, we clearly have a market power held by three major providers, and we bear no liability for negligently created ratings.
Therefore, I request, Mr. Commissioner, that it is good that the consultation is now underway, and we are eager for the results.
I also believe that civil society should participate in this consultation, but then it must also be about putting forward a bold proposal.
I look forward to receiving your proposal.
Let us be as courageous as we have been thus far, and let us together legislate next year in a way that truly resolves the problems that still exist in the rating market on a European scale.
This is what we owe to the citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues! The extent of damage that rating agencies can inflict has been demonstrated by recent months since the beginning of this year.
There is, therefore, an urgent need for action.
Therefore, I welcome the directive, and I welcome it insofar as the ESMA will be entrusted with the supervision and registration of rating agencies.
I believe this is an important and positive step forward.
However, numerous good and constructive suggestions made during the negotiations regarding the report were lost.
I would like to add this here.
The designation of ESMA therefore remains the only genuine and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public data basis for the creation of ratings have been dropped. Likewise, there is no mention of the establishment of a public rating agency.
Even the consistent and continuous review of created ratings by supervisory authorities has fallen by the wayside.
The Commission had continued to propose funding for independent ratings in order to overcome the fateful commissioned assessments of financial market products. Nothing of that has remained either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into consideration in the remaining reports on this topic, which Jean Paul Grosset and also you, Mr. Vannier, have mentioned.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, dear colleagues! First of all, my thanks to those who worked on this report, in particular to Mr. Benson!
I would like to draw attention to two points and perhaps prompt a little reflection.
We agree that energy efficiency, using energy sparingly, is the simplest and most reasonable solution.
The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
I would like to pose the question: What, actually, has it achieved that we have repeatedly confronted the people in Parliament with new and higher percentages?
Have we truly achieved more and accomplished more?
Or why, and in what locations, has energy been handled more efficiently?
I am learning that industry, which consumes a great deal of energy, handles energy efficiently because it saves money and because it is advantageous for them.

I am learning that people, when they know, consume more energy or less energy with this device. So, if they see this and can decide for themselves that there is an advantage, then they will choose it.
It is not really correct to work with percentages, but rather to proceed with incentives in the proper manner.
Second Question The Commissioner has just stated very impressively and clearly how complicated the description of the term "What is it actually?" is on its own.
How differently is this implemented in the member states?
The colleague has just pointed out that the member states also have very different situations—economically, geographically, totally different.
Is it then the correct approach to work with a number, with a binding number, or must we not think of something more?

I believe we must, in energy policy, disentangle ourselves from the debates of the past—debates that, with simple numbers, binding targets, and purported miracle solutions, aimed to achieve something. For it is obvious that we have not achieved enough.
Perhaps we should once try the other path of the differentiated, the varied answers that accommodate the varying situational sensitivities, but then also achieve effect.
It depends on the effects, it does not depend on our state of being.
This regulation, which is being discussed today, has not received much attention in the committees for a long time.
At the end, however, when the result was available, some people in this house awoke.
Some are unfortunately not present for the discussion today. It would have been very, very interesting to hear your perspectives as well.
As a former member of the Convent, the spirit of the Convent remains very, very clear in my memory.
has unequivocally demanded that the European Parliament must obtain specific rights in order to maintain its credibility within the institutions and vis-à-vis citizens.
Consequently, what the convent has given us was still not freely given.
These were extremely difficult negotiations, particularly led by the Belgian presidency vis-à-vis the Council, which have enabled some important progress to be achieved.
I recall what my colleague Lehne already said. That was precisely the question of the constant possibility of verifying whether the Commission has exceeded its competencies.
Naturally, there are some arrangements that are not entirely ideal, such as international trade agreements, but nevertheless I can concur with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian presidency.
He truly put considerable effort into ensuring something would happen and our correspondent, who negotiated with heart and mind.
13, I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a request put forward by my colleague Göran Hägglund on behalf of our group in the Committee on Budgets.
We did not resubmit this amendment, but the Green Party faction has resubmitted the amendment with 40 signatures from Green parliamentarians.
We will abstain from this application.
I also spoke with my colleagues from the Greens about communication. We are absolutely of one mind on the matter.
In principle, however, we as a parliamentary group will not be submitting any new amendment proposals. We will abstain.

I would, however, like to expressly state that we support this point, the Financial Transaction Tax, and hope that our colleagues on the other side of the House and during the votes in the coming days will also support it.
I believe it is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
Particularly in the case of cross-border services, this is especially important. Equal treatment is required here.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price limits were introduced as a crisis tax.
That is unacceptable, particularly financial insurance and commercial industries, but also energy is strongly affected here.
I hope this will not also be employed in the field of healthcare services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orbán to review these regulations, as they completely contradict the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has presented corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is no precise analysis of the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
Even regarding the new proposals, there are scarcely any well-developed calculations and analyses.
I must state that the EPP unequivocally affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
However, consideration of reality also unfortunately leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is being invoked, or even deliberately abused, for entirely different reasons.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for the general immigration of the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers are not given the opportunity to profit from the fate of people through our asylum law, reaping billions in illicit gains.
Asylum procedures must be conducted in a qualified and meticulous manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
Therefore, the Commission is providing for corresponding obligations in the new gatekeepers.
I consider many of these points to be correct, such as interpreting, appropriate medical care, and consideration of specific protection needs.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities in the Member States receive far too few opportunities to counter abuse.
The possibility of conducting expedited proceedings and border proceedings should not be unduly restricted.

If an applicant seriously violates their obligation to cooperate, there are scarcely any means of sanctioning such behavior—quite the opposite. If they abscond illegally, then the member state should no longer be able to terminate their proceedings unfavorably. If they reappear, a broader range of procedural options should be available to them.
Even in cases of obvious lack of merit, an expedited procedure should be possible after the second successive application.
This entails significant cost increases.
Even free legal advice in the form of a lawyer—as is currently stipulated in the Commission's draft—represents a significant increase in costs for the states.
I simply ask the Commission to reconsider the consequences of its proposals for practical reality, the financial implications, and the challenges for the administrations of the Member States.
We want to set a high standard, but it must also be feasible, and we must not present particularly burdened member states with utterly impossible tasks.
Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor once again briefly.
I have a significant request of you, Commissioner Füle.
I want to begin by stating that false assumptions lead to inaccurate cost estimations.
We are not currently seeing decreasing figures in the asylum seeker area, but rather a clearly increasing number.
That relates to visa facilitations, for example, with Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently witnessing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in order to attempt to enter a country of the European Union.

If one proceeds from false assumptions, namely that costs in further instances would be saved by challenging the initial proceedings in a more qualified reform, one automatically assumes, so to speak, that all member states have a deficient initial procedure.
That is not the case.
When one raises standards overall, it consequently means that cost increases will result.
An increase in quality standards for all involved, and also the complication of procedures, I am happy to discuss, but in practical reality leads to higher costs.
Therefore, I earnestly request once again that the concerns of the states be taken seriously, as the practical reports from the states often have lasting value.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen! This report attributes a successful competition policy to the Commission.
However, it must not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and a widening gap between the rich and the poor.
Unfettered competition still prioritizes in the European Union over the social needs of people.
The creed of free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are also incapable of establishing social justice permanently.
Some procedures regarding distortions of competition and price-fixing do not resolve this problem.
A fair and simultaneously social internal market functions only with strong and equitable regulation.
More is urgently needed for that.
It is, for example, not acceptable to perpetually subject public services to private sector competition.
The report formulates indications for the Commission’s future competition policy.

Significantly stronger consumer protection, the exclusion of public utilities from competition regulations, and the control of cartels—
all of this is urgently needed.
Furthermore, a contractual clause for a secured step in social progress would be necessary, one that stands at least on an equal footing with the competition rules in Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is a truly significant moment that we are here today to commemorate, for the first time in the European Parliament, the Holocaust of Oma and Sindi.
Let me begin with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, wrote to him in 1943 before his deportation from a German children’s home to Auschwitz.
He wrote: "I have found my parents again."
We are being transported to the concentration camp.
I have braced myself inwardly to the point that I can endure death.
I thank you once again for everything you have done for me.
Greetings to all, farewell in heaven.

Yours,
Robert!

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500 other Roma and Sinti. And although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, were among the first victims of industrialized mass killings, 66 years later, the full truth about it remains unsaid.
And also the complicity of the mainstream society is often obscured.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be prosecuted as a crime against humanity and acknowledged so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must passionately combat the prejudices against these people.
Racist hostility and acts of violence, as were seen, for example, in Hungary last year, are what we must resolutely oppose, and do so with civic courage.
Freedom and equality and solidarity are not the privilege of individuals, but the right of all, because human and citizen rights are indivisible.
Ladies and gentlemen, esteemed colleagues! From my perspective, the matter now at hand is to truly explore the possibilities of the law within the
To fully exploit the potential for robust financial supervision in Europe, and we have doubts whether institutions are truly maximizing these opportunities.
We observe a lack of procedural transparency. We have not received the candidate list in advance from Parliament, but only the finalized result.
It would be a simple matter to send it to the Executive Directors now.

We have clearly identified the lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions, and we have doubts, due to certain occurrences, whether the Member States are truly appointing individuals to these institutions in the European interest.
And the further points in our letter justify raising a fundamental question.
But beyond that, it naturally concerns the suitability of the individual persons, and in that case, each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There, we see two significant problems.

We have witnessed hearings where one of the candidates disputed that it was a European institution, instead speaking of a network of supervisory authorities, and even upon request, was unwilling to correct this.
In response to the question of whether you are prepared to make all lobbying contacts with the financial industry transparent, we received no clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive answers to it.
Mr. President, Mr. President! We, as the Social Democratic fraction, have the same motion to introduce.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and to this esteemed assembly that we formulate it somewhat more precisely.
We are dealing with a rather substantial influx.

Italy, like every other country in the Mediterranean, is certainly overwhelmed by the prospect of managing the current problem alone. Italy will not be the only country confronted with the mass influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain will also be confronted with this problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, our request would be to formulate the title of the statement very precisely, namely a statement by the Commission concerning immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected in managing the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues! I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

The implementation of the regulation will ensure that, firstly, a high level of protection comparable to that of other modes of transport is now also achieved in the sector of long-distance bus transport, for all passengers, including those with limited mobility.

Firstly, ensuring benefits for consumers are achieved, secondly, guaranteeing a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly, taking into account the particularity that the sector is largely characterized by small and medium-sized enterprises.

Consequently, the extreme demands that would have practically rendered bus traffic impossible due to excessive requirements are off the table, just as are demands under which the majority of member states would have fallen entirely outside the scope of the regulation.
Bus services that benefit the public at large must also provide a high quality of service to disabled people and people with limited mobility.
You should be entitled to assistance. In the interest of social integration, this should be provided free of charge.
Madam President! I would like to congratulate everyone, in particular the colleague Kanzan for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy development of a compromise in this challenging dossier.
There were successes that have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties that have already been described.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have addressed passenger rights for all transport data.
The next necessary step is to establish a common, coherent, and efficient framework program for all passenger modes.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU among European citizens.
To maintain credibility, therefore, the coherence of rights for the various modes of transport must absolutely be respected.
It cannot be otherwise that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of airplane passengers than, for example, to those of train passengers.

Therefore, it is particularly important when developing a framework programme not to adhere to the lowest and weakest standards, but rather to ensure that we do not lose sight of ambitious goals in the interest of citizens.

Madam President, esteemed Mr. President, dear colleagues! We are indeed in a major economic crisis. That’s what we’ve been talking about for months—and that is all correct. However, we generally discuss this in headlines and then cheerfully continue as if nothing had happened here.
I believe it stems from the fact that we, too, in parliament, do not behave specifically enough, nor honestly enough, but rather it is such a policy of headlines that occurs.
What, in reality, does one actually do to promote growth and stability?
Are we ourselves also contributing to handling finances more properly and wisely?
Have we truly conducted a critical examination of whether we are making the right expenditures, or does each of us not have a new idea every day regarding where more money can be spent?

If we do not have the strength to concentrate financial resources on future projects—that is to say, conflict, disagreement, and decisions—then there is no point in talking about innovation and research, but not providing the means for it.
That is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we must also pursue policies that stimulate it, rather than spending from morning till night contemplating how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We cheerfully continue to pass resolutions, demanding new resolutions even today, which disrupt economic developments.
I believe that citing the question of binding energy efficiency targets as an example demonstrates a contribution to driving economic progress.
Do you genuinely believe that our decisions, which we have frequently made in the context of energy, have stimulated the economy?
Or have we disturbed them?
I would like us to be a little more honest about this and then make fewer decisions, but perhaps decisions that truly move things forward.
That is more demanding, will also mean contention, but that is the essence of democracy.
Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues! The demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. For several years now, opponents of globalization have been calling for such a tax.
Yet, just five years ago, few would have believed that they could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week, it is on the agenda in the European Parliament alongside a carbon tax and Eurobonds, and I think that is a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments Annie Polimamata proposes in her report, and I believe we will also adjust them accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has thus far focused solely on reducing expenditures.
The reduction in public expenditure primarily affects employees, pensioners, and the poor – those who depend on the welfare state.
The revenue side of government has hitherto been completely overlooked.
It is the second adjustment knob one can turn to consolidate public finances.
Above all, however, those primarily responsible for the public debt crisis and the reduction of public debt can also be appropriately involved on the revenue side.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenues is simply indispensable.

In reality, the high level of public sector debt is primarily a consequence of the nationalization of private debt, namely the assumption of private banks' liabilities and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by the public sector.
The responsibility for the debt crisis, therefore, does not lie with the states alone.
It is therefore not only natural, but also politically imperative, to call the financial sector to account.
The financial transaction tax would finally involve this sector, identified as a primary cause of public debt, in its repayment.
This is an important political signal emanating from this report, should it be adopted as presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to debt reduction than all sanctions or well-intentioned advice, however qualified.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens would increase due to Eurobonds are, however, unacceptable, because at the same time, these surplus countries also profit from their exports to deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
Whoever desires a social Europe, whoever wants the EU to remain united in the future, must in principle at least agree to a transfer union.
Finally, I would like to address the Commission and express my hope that you will now finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax, which have been requested for over a year.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The rescue shields were intended to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, you are burdening people with brutal austerity programs while leaving the perpetrators unscathed. Furthermore, the Commission is now also intervening in national wage policies.
Dear Hahn, it is absurd, and it brings tears to one's eyes to see this formal argumentation as if it were not intended to be socio-political at all.
This position is entirely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the responsibility of the EU. This policy of the Commission is in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union has never been a project for a race to the bottom in wages and social dumping.
There is discussion to be had, there is reading to be done about wage rigidity, which should be reduced.
That is to say, wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, the blind are talking about color; those who formulate such statements have no understanding whatsoever of collective bargaining agreements.
They intervene in collective bargaining autonomy and render the long-established autonomy of social partners and social dialogue absurd.

I want to state clearly that this Parliament is required to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue, and to prevent further erosion of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policy actions. Thank you.
Barroso is a clever man, but he did not answer my question.

Therefore, I ask again: If Mr. Oettinger says, "We have the current suspicion that certain installations connected to the grid will not survive our stress tests," I interpret that as meaning you are aware that these installations are so poorly secured that they will not meet the criteria.
Why don't you intervene today already?
For me, that is a real danger.

Mrs. Gabriele Zimmer has the floor.
I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why they believe they need to address this topic with soundbites.
I believe it helps no one if it is stated very explicitly that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the member states of the European Union and the European Union
It must finally fulfill its commitments regarding development assistance, and it cannot be tolerated in any way that member states increasingly evade this obligation.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still hunger every day and that the majority of them live in LDCs, that is, in the poorest countries of the world.

It is unacceptable that a large portion of our development aid is not directed towards the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but that this proportion has rapidly declined in recent years, particularly with a billion people suffering from hunger.
And then to talk about that. We hope that the LDC will be more shock-resistant. I am slowly coming to believe that.
I urge you to address the problems specifically and clearly, and to undertake concrete commitments to genuinely assist the LDC.
In connection with the internal market, public procurement law—the awarding of public contracts—is a crucial component.

Mr. Barnier, when you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I must ask you: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
That belongs to the fundamental rules that you, as you say, do not wish to question yourself.

If one wishes to protect fundamental rules, it will be necessary in the future when awarding public contracts to ensure that elementary social standards are protected, that collective bargaining agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is prevented.
That belongs to a modern, a modernized public procurement law.
I expressly state that social basic rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe, or we want a permanent conflict with the people who are turning away from this Europe, who do not see their vital interests safeguarded within it. Thank you very much.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner K Cruz! Radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and considering societal aspects as a whole.
Therefore, the Radio Spectrum Policy Programme assumes particular significance.
Radio frequencies must be utilized efficiently, taking into consideration economic, social, and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, technical possibilities must be utilized to the fullest extent across all bandwidth ranges to generate maximum efficiency.

Based on radio frequency policy, the telecommunications package adopted last year must be the framework, as it also stipulated that radio frequency management for the EU and its member states must equally serve cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be considered particularly when harmonizing frequency usage within the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I has been progressing at a highly varied pace across the member states.
A further opening of the URF band, particularly below 800 Megahertz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experiences gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions have not yet been conclusively resolved.

The interference issues and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local administrative bodies during technical upgrades, for example in the area of radio microphones, have not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
In the allocation of frequency bands, the diverse interests must be responsibly balanced against one another.

Widespread provision of mobile broadband networks is, on the one hand, a fundamental requirement in the interest of European citizens. Simultaneously, however, continued development in the area of public and private broadcasting must also be considered as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must set the course correctly for technological development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn! I would first like to say that you have described it—the situation has worsened.
The Eurozone: the gap is widening between countries that are recovering and those that are performing more weakly.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries continue to rise.

In this situation, I have some questions for you. As Currency Commissioner, I ask you: On that day, two clients of the ECB system accumulated liabilities and receivables between the national central banks amounting to over 400 billion euros.
This is because banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities that are not provided for by the Eurosystem?
The major problem preventing progress with debt restructuring is that the banking system, as Ms. Ford also stated, is not properly structured.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present it?
And how do you, as Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, assess this delay?
What are you doing to make it go faster?
Then we saw how we had already predicted this earlier, that the measures against Greece would not affect Portugal, as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone did not improve.
We have increasingly high, still absolutely increasing interest burdens macroeconomically for these countries.
We are observing increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
We still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, particularly from the stronger Eurozone countries.
And we have rising resource and food prices, at least if one excludes the most recent peaks and troughs.

Besides the bailout for these countries, besides the aid on the financing side, what measures are being taken to ensure that the weaker countries can steer themselves macroeconomically on these fronts—the front of external demand, the question of interest rate relief?
And how
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that macroeconomically improves the conditions of these countries within the Eurozone.

Finally, in my view, the measures have affected the most vulnerable in countries like Greece, Portugal, and Spain, while the stronger—the wealthier—have not yet been brought to bear a share of the burden.
What measures are you taking to ensure that those with assets also contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Mr. President Mr. President! Ms. Gia Gönz is a member of my parliamentary group.
One can be opposed to Ferenc Jószána, one can be in favor of Ferenc Jószána.
One can reject Kingergg as a politician or support her.
It is certainly possible for anyone to freely and independently determine whether one holds a political conviction contrary to that of another person.
The debate we are conducting here is about the last dictatorship that exists in Europe.
We will guide you through the life of one of the most brutal and bloody dictators to have existed on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that a freely elected democratic member of my faction is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I believe that Parliament must also reject this, particularly from a representative of a party that distinguishes itself by subjecting the Roma minority in Hungary to a hatred and persecution unparalleled in Europe.
If anyone is not entitled to criticize Mrs. Kingerönz, then it is.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, and dear guests! The cultural diversity of Europe is a valuable asset that must be preserved and further expanded in the future.
To achieve this, we must confront the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but also a significant economic factor.
Approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector within the EU.
This corresponds to approximately two and a half percent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector, developing more rapidly than many areas of the broader economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven just as much by the content offered by the cultural sector as the technology itself has changed and advanced the nature and quality of that content.
We therefore require framework conditions for the culture and creative industries that will allow them to develop sustainably in view of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible, and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and the creative industries are a driver for Europe.
Therefore, we must also focus on this area within the domains of school and vocational education.
We must impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also within the offerings of lifelong learning.
We must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators, and not only entrepreneurial competencies but also good media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which culture creators can earn their living.
Therefore, we will need to engage intensively with the issues of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, as well as open access to information and content, in order to

to ensure that the creative and cultural industries thrive in a digital environment in the future and to be able to preserve Europe’s cultural diversity and cultural heritage as an essential characteristic of the European Union.
Mr. President, dear colleague Kelllam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues! Today, we commemorate in particular the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions belong to the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was, not only and again not least for this reason, also and not unjustly called a century of displacements.
We all bow our heads today before the victims of these inhumane acts.
In this context, we demand a comprehensive elucidation of Soviet history and, in particular, the devastating consequences of Stalinism.

Today’s Russia should not interpret this as a political assault, but rather as support for grappling with its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is marked by both bright and shadowed aspects.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the following century.
We consider the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
A particular high point of deportations in Europe was reached in the mid-century by the Nazi Regime and by the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
Expulsions after the Second World War also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav Wars.
However, we must also not forget that many colonial regimes were characterized by displacement.
We must demand a serious engagement with the various forms of dispossession and the spurious justifications thereof.
Included is the clarification of guilt and the punishment of the guilty, insofar as it is still possible, as is now the case with Mlade.
But the decisive answer lies in European unity, particularly through and with the autonomous Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the still-incomplete European integration process.
This historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but particularly to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries of Europe, from East and West, have worked on this.
Let us consider, for example, the Danzig Declaration signed by the Polish President Weisniewski and the German Federal President Ra.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant, even regarding initial signs of displacement, as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all such statements, for example, the assertion that Arab migrants should be returned in boats across the Mediterranean. And we must resist when some seek to dismantle the achievements of Europe without borders and to usher in a new, restrictive nationalism.

Let us bow our heads in Erfurt, particularly in remembrance of the expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously affirm our commitment to the continuation of European unification as the only genuine guarantee.
a policy that has brought so much misfortune to the people of Europe across the way in the past century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have lost none of their validity; they are best safeguarded within a united Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, my esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I had the opportunity, as a parliamentary observer, to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan, and I was impressed by the strong support of South Sudanese people for wanting to determine the fate of their country themselves in the future.
I also observed the great expectation among the people, who viewed their country’s independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands of so-called internally displaced persons, driven by decades of conflict in the south to refugee camps in the north, set out for their former southwestern Danish homeland.

Naturally, the people of South Sudan, in addition to the country’s independence, above all desire a path to a happier future while living in peace, after all those decades of armed conflicts in which millions of South Sudanese have had to forfeit their lives.
On July 9th, the new state of South Sudan is now scheduled to officially become independent and expand the family of nations in our world.
The state of affairs is exceedingly poor, and much has already been said about this.
The percentage of people live as norvanizing livestock breeders, 80% are illiterate. The conflict over Abillé is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already casualties and injured.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also escalating, and according to estimates by observers, more than a thousand people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and the violated are scarcely counted.
Sudan already belonged to the category of failed states.
There is a risk that the state of South Sudan is already beginning to resemble a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that there is a significant obligation of Europe toward these regions.

Given the colonial past of the countries in question, together with the UN and the African Union, a common European foreign policy is needed here, and it can demonstrate its effectiveness here as well.
It is not only about money, but also about supporting the delicate, emerging civil society.

We must negotiate firmly with those whose fate rests upon it—namely, the Stamels leaders, commanders of the military groups—that you do not disappoint the hope of your people in the land. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues! I am very grateful to my colleague Bartolotti for having made Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament with his initiative for this request.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now treated from different perspectives in parliament, the Molkangolei and their situation found very little resonance here.
Quite undeservedly, it was Mongolia that, early on, capitalized on its independence and embarked on a path toward the democratization of its society, formerly the starting point of a communist blog.

As early as 1992, Mongolia adopted a democratic constitution, and several elections have since taken place, which, according to observers, proceeded overall in a democratic and correct manner—a situation that is far from assured in states of this region.

The Mongolian government has been attempting to combat corruption by law for several years and issued a moratorium on the death penalty in 2010, a feat that even some large democratic states have yet to achieve.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this geographically large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, suffer the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
Thus, a rural population, still predominantly living a nomadic lifestyle, is pressing into the few towns that are not prepared infrastructurally for this influx.
The country’s natural resources are not extracted in an environmentally damaging manner.
Energy problems complicate civilian and economic life.
Squeezed between the large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia faces an even greater risk of becoming dependent on these states.

The efforts and the successes of Mongolia—and here I see the glass half full, not half empty. In the democratization of society, it should be acknowledged that they are exemplary for this region and demonstrate what is possible despite a difficult past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only within the framework of aid programs, but also by ensuring the European Union has a direct presence in the Mongolian capital with its own

Representation as a sign that the fate of the Mongolian region and Europeans is not a matter of indifference and that European interests will no longer be pursued from a representation in Peking. One sentence, please.
I deeply regret that the Conference of Presidents did not show itself willing to further emphasize this concern by approving a resolution of the Parliament. Thank you very much.

Consequently, I have not entirely understood the meaning of your question, but what I believed I gathered was that you, too, feel aligned with democracy.
That is at least a step forward.

Firstly, I reacted so agitatedly because I am still upset about the fact that we failed to reach a joint resolution on security measures to get here, because the absolutism of a position was deemed more important than common ground.

Secondly, I explained in the debate at the time, and I am explaining it again now, that I too earned additional income back then, and I now see that we must do more, apply more pressure, and show more initiative in the area of stricter regulations for European power plants.
That is precisely why I was in favor of the joint resolution, and that is why I am in favor of you supporting the Commissioner and me permanently challenging him.

Ladies and gentlemen! To the intermediate category! Initially, I certainly could have envisioned other solutions, Mr. Pieper, for example, providing a transitional arrangement for the region that currently has the highest demand and will no longer have it after 2013.
The discussion revealed, however, that we must consider further regions, particularly those affected by the crisis.
We are discussing regions presently.
Given the number of regions affected, it would be almost negligent not to establish an intermediate category.
Only in this way can a reliable framework for the responsible promotion of this region be established, which, after all, must overcome developmental deficits with its own strength.

We criticize, among other things, the lack of a clear commitment to a far more decisive fight against poverty, and we consider formulations, such as those contained herein, linking cohesion policy with conditionality that compels Member States to implement reforms, to be unclear and overly broad in their interpretation.
The cohesion policy must remain an instrument of social equity and solidarity throughout all regions.
Mr. President, my esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! International cooperation will increasingly gain in importance in the future.
Cross-border cooperation and macroregional collaboration are exceptionally important for achieving the 2020 ski goals within an increasingly integrated Europe.
Border regions still face particular challenges today.

Cross-border concepts and projects, such as those in the fields of infrastructure, corporate cooperation, research collaboration, labor market development, and vocational training, are a driving force for large parts of the European Union.
We require clear and simplified structures in the processing of interregional projects.
Different national requirements among project partners frequently impede cooperation and the realization of concrete, sustainable projects.
It is an important step that the Piper Report incorporates the demand for an expansion of the share for interregional cooperation under Target 3 to 7, and I would like to strongly support this.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues! After nearly three years of intensive work, after far more than 3 amendments, after countless conversations, discussions

Debates Following the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogue, it is now up for vote. The political package—a major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council—regarding the future labeling of foodstuffs.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that is not all. The European food industry is also to benefit.
Legal certainty, final bureaucratization, and improved legislation are the goal.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it is essential to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80% SMEs.
Simultaneously, this labelling must be appropriate for every food and every non-alcoholic beverage, from staple foods to highly processed ready meals.
Therefore, a mandatory label in traffic light colors is also not possible, because such a label simply does not suit basic foodstuffs.
Despite all difficulties, despite all political ideological differences in Parliament, despite all national egoisms of the member states, the compromise now achieved is nonetheless impressive.
Allergens will be clearly identifiable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is an origin indication for pork, poultry, mutton, and goat meat.

For further products, a consequence assessment will show whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example for milk and milk products, single ingredients (i.e., products consisting of a primary ingredient), and meat in processed
Products etc. Imitations must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to products composed and assembled from small pieces of “Formfleisch” and “Form Fisch.”
Packaging must not create the impression that it contains something which it does not.
If a picture of fruit is on a yogurt container, then fruit must also be inside, and not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, the mandatory indication of the most important nutrients is always given per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be indicated, the date of the first freezing of meat and fish, and many other details.
Above all, all information must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have established a minimum font size, and the commission has been tasked with defining binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between text and background.
Simultaneously, we protect crafts at high cost and with significant bureaucracy.
Unpackaged fresh products are required to provide allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information, which would require expensive analyses.

The Commission originally wanted this, but that would have destroyed our national and regional peculiarities and specialties; it would have led to a European homogenized mass, and that is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the serious consumer advocates are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would therefore like to thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs of the Commission, in particular Commissioner Dalli for his statements, which he will hopefully deliver shortly and with which the knot that has formed amongst us in political discourse will be untangled.

I would like to express particular thanks to the Hungarian presidency of the Council, which has achieved something that was almost no longer to be expected, almost the squaring of the circle – reaching agreement on this regulation.
Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, esteemed Polish Presidency of the Council! Allow me to join your thanks to the rapporteur, Ms. Ayyala Sender.

The change in the legal basis from European transport policy to police cooperation has finally enabled the Council to draft a common position.
This, however, means that some countries, such as Great Britain, Ireland, and Denmark, are excluded.
Consequently, not all European citizens are equal once again.
Citizens must be clear about the rights they possess regarding data protection.
We have sought to strengthen this aspect to ensure that access to collected data, its transmission, and its storage are regulated as strictly as possible.
We also held this information in very high regard.
Although the witty text does not fully meet the Parliament's expectations, I remain optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that we can continue to build upon this foundation in the coming years, thereby taking a step towards a more intensive harmonization of European traffic regulations.
The revision clause inserted by Parliament will certainly permit such action.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues! First of all, heartfelt thanks to Ms. Kollegin Matthias for this report!

must not only grasp, but also prove that we are serious about research and innovation—that is the crucial question for the future viability of the European Union.

We are receiving research funding more effectively designed.

And that, I believe, is an important task that still needs to be resolved.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! In view of the currently exceptional situation as a result of the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at the European level should focus on urgent and essential matters.
Only in this way can we restore trust among our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report concerns the strategy for avoiding endless human suffering, resulting from approximately 35 fatalities and over
5 million often severe injuries as a result of traffic accidents, as well as to avoid the associated economic damage of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of fatalities alone corresponds to what would be mourned in the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized commercial aircraft.
What wouldn't we do to prevent that?
The total cost of accident consequences considerably exceeds the annual overall budget of the European Union.
Therefore, I am confident that it would serve us well to become sustainably active in this area.

Thanks to the constructive work of all shadow rapporteurs as well as many colleagues, we have, for the first time with this report, succeeded in developing a holistic and coherent approach to improving road safety.

It considers the content of the UN Decade of Action for Road Safety 2010–2020 as well as the content and objectives of road safety initiatives undertaken by EU Member States and broader circles of civil society.
It first includes ambitious, yet realistic goals for the period until 2020 and with the Vision SEERROM for the time thereafter.
Therefore, the goal is to reduce the number of traffic fatalities by 50, the number of child fatalities even by 60, and the number of severely injured individuals by 40 by 2020.
That lies in the most fundamental interest of each individual among us, but also in our national economy.
We recommend that Member States break down targets and methods to their territory and expect them to develop their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it specifies who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is far more than just the European Union.

In the spirit of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that member states, regional or municipal entities, and indeed each individual road user in the context of their obligation to cooperate, also have a responsibility to assume.
Thirdly, it specifies how – that is, with which instruments, activities, and measures – the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are only one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to forgo guidelines, recommendations, and mandates.
Particular attention was paid to the principle of subsidiarity. This means that responsibilities and accountabilities were clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

However, given that you are coming from a diverse range of directorates-general, such as Transport, Economy, Consumer Protection, Environment, Communications, Research and Development, Internal Market, and others, your statements are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes contradictory.
Therefore, we propose the establishment of a coordinator for road safety within the European Commission.
This permanently avoids the establishment of an agency for road safety, but dramatically increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data definitions and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as EU-wide data exchange while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six key areas of action were identified.
They pertain to people as road users, traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking, as well as the special consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request your approval, tomorrow.
Esteemed President, esteemed colleagues! Yes, we are to focus on pressing and essential topics in traffic safety.
I am very convinced of this, and from my perspective, it primarily concerns the two greatest distractors in road traffic: alcohol and excessive speed.
Here, the European Union must also have something to say, and not just propose technical measures, which, in my view, are good but by far not sufficient.
Above all in cities, the lack of attention is particularly dramatic a problem of inattentive drivers.
Therefore, the speed must be reduced here.
I was very pleasantly surprised that a broad majority supported 30 km/h zones as a recommendation.

Particular consideration must be given – and this is also included – and I believe it to be important and beneficial – to finally bringing vulnerable road users into the focus of attention. I hope that these measures will, in the end, be implemented.
It seems pointless to me, but I would like to extend an invitation to him.

the condition that industries in Europe, which are unduly burdened by this, can be relieved, because otherwise they will not be able to withstand competition with other regions of the world.

It’s not just about steel; it’s about aluminum. You know, it’s about many other areas of chemistry and so on, that one simply doesn’t implement what was, at the time, the political basis of the decision.

We are facing a completely new situation; we have a considerably more competitive environment.
We are all striving for this and declaring here in Sunday speeches that industries are a vitally important area for Europe’s future development.

I expect that Parliament expects – and I believe this to be the case – that what was agreed upon then will also be implemented now, and specifically in favor of industry, not industry itself, but the people who work in these companies, the jobs, and thus also Europe’s future prospects.
Do you know of any example that would actually justify the effort—that one spends many millions, that is, billions—to develop these body scanners?

Mr. President! I would first like to thank the representative of the Council for the very clear description of the current situation.
Throughout this debate, we have consistently heard that it concerns improving the situation for working women who are considering having a child.
In my view, the directive places too much emphasis on increasing maternity leave to 20 weeks.
But do we truly believe that the decision to have a child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity leave?

As a mother of three children, I am very well aware that comprehensive concepts for offers and good family-oriented offers are necessary to positively influence the decision for a child and to establish equality of opportunity for women.
The present draft guideline does not even remotely do justice to the very good offer concepts and overall concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that are responsive to the situation in member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful thinking will not lead to a solution here.
Therefore, we must first develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
The comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children have the highest priority.
This can be ensured in various ways with different models.
Someone who wants to bash their way through a wall will not necessarily reach their goal faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise opens no doors and builds no bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution and for more maternal protection, in order to progress here.

I believe that we truly still need to seek an approach based on the Commission's draft directive that provides greater flexibility for different concepts in the individual member states to significantly improve both maternity protection for women and the protection of children in the first months of life.
That will not work with the draft presented here today, which certainly did not command a large majority, as some colleagues have attempted to make clear today.
I desire a bit more flexibility here, a bit more realism, and a somewhat better view of what the Member States have already achieved, without calling our fundamental demands into question.
Madam President, Commissioner! I would like to make a few remarks on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have done already.
Instead of preventing tax evasion, which would be sensible, or closing loopholes for tax dodgers, what has been produced here is a Swiss cheese with large holes.
The proposed transition period of five months is sufficient time and tax acumen to transfer funds from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement; however, it is also sufficient to convert assets located in Switzerland into foundation assets.
Corresponding forms are available at Swiss banks.
The German tax authorities received information some time ago regarding several tax evaders who have concealed their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement grants these individuals an amnesty, and tax investigators are no longer permitted to further utilize the information at their disposal.
What kind of agreement is this that shackles the tax authorities?
Accordingly, the advertising video of Swiss banks also states that customers will continue to benefit from the values of the Swiss financial center in the future.

This agreement evidently lacks not only the necessary coordination at the EU level, but also runs counter to the EU's efforts to increase transparency in tax matters. I conclude that it hinders the objective of designing tax collection in the Member States more efficiently and, above all, combating and preventing tax fraud.
Therefore, it cannot be acceptable from our perspective.
this agreement and we ask the EU to strongly advocate against it in cases of doubt. Thank you.

Madam President! I am pleased that, together with Roberta Angelilli’s report, we have managed to launch a sustainable and effective directive, and I would like to thank her for that.
The directive then represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of one thing. The vast majority of crimes still occur within children’s closest social environments.
The perpetrators are to be found within families, schools, and circles of acquaintances.
And here we still stand at the beginning of our educational work.

Therefore, our children must be empowered, strong enough to have the courage to confide in a close person in a serious situation, but also strong enough to recognize dangers such as grooming when using the internet.
We must therefore work together to ensure that a sense of responsibility in dealing with media plays a greater role in the education of our children.
In this context, education is of the greatest importance, as many teachers and parents are simply unaware of what is possible with their children’s computers or mobile phones.
I believe that represents a significant backlog.

It is therefore to be welcomed that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, as authorities, but also schools and families, must do everything possible to prevent these utterly abhorrent crimes from occurring in the first place.
Consequently, more effective negotiation strategies for the EU with third countries, such as the United States and Russia, are also required.

Pages stored outside the EU can only be effectively and swiftly deleted if we also work closely with these countries in the investigation of the perpetrators and jointly send a clear signal against the sexual exploitation of children.
Once the perpetrator has been apprehended, the legislature has often been surprisingly lenient thus far, suspending the majority of offenses only on probation.
Here, the severity of the offense should be given greater consideration in the future.
Overall, however, it is important that the public debate continues, as the topic encompasses a wide range of dimensions.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, extinguishing in front of barriers, legal precedents, education, and intensive scientific documentation of the incident must continue to be advanced even after the coordination meeting tomorrow.
It is imperative that we do not simply fold our arms.
Rather, we must embrace the directive in its entirety, each of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Mr. President! For years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at roughly the same level.
In this process, the tasks of the EU have continuously expanded, and the financial requirements have risen significantly.
Thus, new institutions necessary for financial market supervision have been established.
To effectively perform their duties, these institutions, however, require sound financial resources.
As a consequence of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become readily apparent.
To strengthen the economies of these countries, a comprehensive economic stimulus program would be necessary.
Some experts even speak of the necessity of a Marshall Plan for the crisis-ridden EU countries.
The EU does not need austerity programs that stifle growth, but rather an expenditure program that promotes growth—one that secures work and income for workers and for young people in the EU.
But what does the council do in this situation?
He abbreviates the draft proposal, which already falls far short of necessities.

If, in the current political situation, a reasonable increase in the budget cannot be achieved, then Parliament and the Commission should nevertheless do everything possible to ward off the proposed cuts by the Council.
That makes things more difficult. Ladies and gentlemen, precisely now, in this crisis, it becomes clear what kind of European Union we truly want.

Do we want a Union where the KiIT also functions as a connecting link, and do we state that we do not find it indifferent whether people are forced to live in poverty in any Member State of the European Union?
Let us see ourselves in the shared responsibility of fighting against poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we opt for a union as it has just been outlined by the colleagues from the far-right faction of this Parliament?

Sometimes I believe that we are dangerously close to a vision of the European Union as formulated by the far right, given the attitude of the member states and, in particular, some governments of those member states.
Absolutely nothing shared, no common instruments employed, no common indicators established, vague formulations wherever possible.
The Third Report makes this very, very clear on many points, and I believe we must become considerably stronger here.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sell-off of public assets, the sell-off of social security systems.
We require social and ecological minimum standards.
In view of the impending winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the street, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death due to rising energy prices.
Here, we bear a shared responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
For this, we must advocate, and not for this nationalist drivel, which we have heard from the right wing.
What advice would we have given our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, when a depression existed, when financial markets were already undermining democracies, and when they were headed for war?
I believe two things would be necessary, two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you must do, swiftly. Do not be held back. Regulate every product, every institution, and every player, like that!
Merkel has said, but a transitional government alone, which enforces the austerity program in financial policy, cannot have a future if there is no austerity program in democratic policy.

Many thanks, Madam President. There is no doubt that this House champions transparency and openness towards the citizenry.

In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative organizations, etc., should also be published. Where is the public interest?

I believe this report is not in the spirit of our citizens.
He would unleash a deluge of superfluous information.

Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! When dealing with such an important and unsuitable topic as the White Paper on the Future of Transport, the risk is always great that one ends up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to squeeze in their two or three wish topics.
When one considers the result that will be put to a vote tomorrow, there is no doubt that we can congratulate our rapporteur, Matthieu Grosch.

He managed to distill several hundred suggestions into a good, a coherent, and manageable result, which emphasizes safety, environmental protection, energy, and technology as the main priorities for transport in the future.
I expressly welcome the fact that important issues such as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are also appropriately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in light of the looming skills shortage in the transport sector, against which active measures must be taken if future bottlenecks in well-trained specialists are to be prevented.
Further liberalization of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given a significant place here.
The safety on our roads is a topic that will continue to concern us also in the future.
I view other points with greater criticality.
I would have preferred a statement regarding the model ship, where more emphasis would be placed on shifting traffic from the road to the rail network and waterways.
For this reason, I believe the discussion surrounding Gigaliners is not the best solution for greater sustainability.
Equally critical, one should monitor and reconsider the further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport.
There remain technical harmonizations to resolve in order to ensure fair competitive conditions.

But as stated in this report, I hope that expressing the expectations of Parliament here does not remain a pious wish list, but that a goal is achieved by 2020 and our proposals have become reality. Thank you.

It has been only 20 years since the Central Asian states gained their state sovereignty as a result of the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

Nevertheless, these states are important trade partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU’s relations with these states within the framework of Partnership and Cooperation Agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to facilitate collaboration and promote partnership-based action, but not to lead to one-sided stigmatization.
Child labour, and especially forced child labour, remain a widespread scourge in many countries of the world, and one that must be combatted.

However, I must point out that it was common in many agriculturally characterized European regions to extend children's school holidays during harvest time and to allow children from farming families the opportunity to assist with the harvest, which today would not be considered forced labor.
However, should there be indications of child labor in Uzbekistan during the cotton harvest, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence, however, must apply to all other states where child labor still exists, including those states in which we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as in India or in China.
We should not apply double standards here.

have and, in fact, new cases are already arising due to the pressure being built to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the private banking sector.
