Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! It surprises me that we repeatedly have to be reminded what cohesion policy actually entails.

Cohesion policy and structural policy are among the central policy areas of the European Union, and they are, by definition, intended to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, and in doing so, to particularly promote growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been demonstrated particularly in the years of the crisis.
In many regions, the prospects for economic development would appear considerably more challenging were these funds not available.
The implementation of the structure of funding is thus based on operational programs. This has already been pointed out, where the funding strategy of the respective region is described.
The European Union, Member States, and regions collaborate here in a partnership, thereby creating genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy also relies on the reliability of the programs and the resources made available and standing by.

Therefore, I am very surprised when, repeatedly, both from Member States and, as we now see, from the Commission's side, there are attempts to treat Structural Funds as a savings account for all sorts of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the sense and purpose of cohesion policy and, moreover, unsettles the actors in the regions who are already working towards achieving the objectives based on long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and advocating for economic growth are important objectives.

This will only be achieved, however, if the collaborative partnership between the regions, the Member States, and the Commission is maintained and the actors in the regions are involved and remain so.
Only you possess the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Cohesion and structural policy represent the genuine, solidarity-based bond of action between the various levels of policy within the European Union.
In it, solidarity in Europe becomes visible locally, in the regions, and it should not be lightly abandoned due to political expediency.

A tremendous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure, disadvantaging you compared to your colleagues in 22 member states.

They are not fighting for additional rights for authors here, but rather against individuals to whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is intended to guarantee equal access to cultural goods, and who should also be able to participate fully in these cultural goods.

Dear colleagues,

The discussion here within these walls demonstrates that we essentially represent the entire spectrum, on one side those who desire no restrictions whatsoever, and on the other side, those who associate any form of immigration with the endangerment of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this household.
I believe one must consider family reunification with considerable reason and also with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in Member States where overly restrictive measures have been implemented.
For family reunification cannot be encumbered with so many obstacles that ultimately no one can be reunited.
On the other hand, it is entirely legitimate for member states to require, for example, language proficiency, to demand integration, but also to require a willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, Member States naturally have the right, and we should not dismiss these issues, the problems that arise in the context of family reunification, to articulate them.

When countries like Greece or Malta, or indeed Romania or Italy, are no longer permitted to articulate the problems they face in part in this context, then I do not know any longer whether we are democratic if we simply ignore problems.
I don’t believe we need another new guideline just yet.
I believe we should carefully discuss the problems and then consider how we can eliminate them.
The constant re-production of guidelines does not lead to an improvement in the guidelines and their implementation.
We are currently experiencing implementation challenges in some areas.

I also fully understand the need to first grapple with the fact that we should not again create a new directive and add something to it before we have thoroughly discussed the problems of the existing directive in any way.
I am in favor of listening to the member states and, simultaneously, respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
If one does this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will come to a good path.

we have now been able to ascertain.

Numbers sometimes say more than grand words, and to this day, the European Parliament—as you also mentioned—the European Patent Office has granted almost 2,200 patents on plants and nearly 1,200 patents on animals, which originated with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I would like to mention two outstanding examples: the granting of patents for genetically modified and bred barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Consequently, our farmers, our brewers, and we, the consumers, are affected.

Second example, the so-called LongLiToate – not to be confused with its LongLi oil, which you have in the engines of your diesel motors.
With this tactic employed by the requesting US corporation Arcadia, this patent bypassed the valid EU regulations.
It is not the tomato that has been patented, but its genetic material, namely selected enzymes.

We are of the opinion that this definition must be clarified; it must be interpreted precisely.
Technical procedures employed to support conventional addiction treatment must not lead to patentability in general.
We are not, specifically, claiming a patent on life.
We need a clear signal here for greater ethics and greater honesty in dealing with creation, once again opposing patentability of life throughout Europe.
Mr. Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are prohibited in Europe and will remain so.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive: no patents on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of numerous farmers and breeders across Europe, we demand a clear and unambiguous codification of breeder and farmer privilege throughout all legislation. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to address the discharge of Europol and Eurojust.
Regarding Europol, there is little to no cause for criticism.
The annual financial statements present a true and fair view of the financial situation as of 2010, and all underlying transactions comply with regulations and are therefore also lawful.
Noticeable are only the high carryovers in relation to the overall, actually low accumulated costs.
Europol attributes this to the relocation to a new headquarters. This is, of course, understandable.
However, Europol has pledged to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
Furthermore, Europol intends to commit to monthly monitoring of the budget's execution from 2012 onward.
I recommend that we keep track of whether that actually happens.
Against this backdrop, I recommend relieving the burden on Europol.
Regarding Eurojust, the annual financial report also reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects.
Transactions are also lawful and compliant here.
But here, too, high operating expenses were carried forward to the year 2011.
Following the justification for EuroIst, this was primarily attributable to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure, and costs associated with data processing.
It is announced that everything will be improved in the future, including better adherence to tender requirements.
I recommend that we continue to review this in the future as well, and above all, verify whether all open positions will indeed be filled in the future.
It has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we will almost have to consider cutting funds, which would be detrimental to Orrius.
I still recommend relief. Thank you.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! What should alarm and unsettle us is not the sheer number of young unemployed people in Europe alone, but the development.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of young unemployed individuals increased by 26.5 percent. This is according to the International Labour Organization.

It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not merely disconnecting an entire generation from the labor market; we are disconnecting an entire generation from a future worth living.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we shouldn't be surprised when they turn away from this EU, because they lack reasonable employment and life prospects.

Sir Inspector, I urgently request that you ensure decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already perceive certain developments, but please ensure that this long-standing intellectual stagnation does not devolve into operational frenzy!
When I read that the Commission is launching a program to financially support young people who apply for positions abroad, then we are organizing a hiking group – that does not solve the problem.
On the contrary, it will prove counterproductive. Technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff will then be poached from states that are wealthier, that are not in this crisis.
Now, in this crisis, offensive measures are needed to address the cause of this development, namely the dismantling of this reserve that impacts the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need a strengthening of domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that creates a life perspective for young people.
Finally, this youth unemployment situation also does not tolerate the proposition of raising the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labor market.
Therefore, I urgently request a thank you.
Colleague, you stated that anything in favor of the financial transaction tax would be speculation, and then proceeded to offer very speculative examples yourself.

I would like to know from you, in light of what you have said, what you then think of these investigations of the Commission and the Commission's study, which very clearly states that, thus far, far too little consideration has been given to the real economy in its dependence on

the financial markets that 95 percent of companies are in no way dependent on for raising capital and that one can indeed turn the negative growth effect, of which we have previously spoken, into a positive one by making corresponding public investments that promote growth.
Is this merely speculation on your part, or would you say that such a well-founded, broad-ranging study by the Commission also has its justification and represents a strong argument?

Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues! The financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been discussed and debated for many years. However, I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She takes at least the idea of taxing the financial markets and, above all, making them bear the costs of the crisis.
I believe this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
That is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
In a number of member states, there were numerous actions, petitions, and written appeals to politicians to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I believe the parliament has achieved a significant success with the majority that has here endorsed this report and this tax.
Certainly, it is not sufficient to stabilize and restrict the financial markets as might perhaps be necessary. But I believe it is a truly important step that has been taken.
I would like to expressly appeal to the council to take the voices of the voters seriously and to advocate for them.
that a genuine introduction occurs, that it is not blocked in the Council, due to the British position or other positions, regarding the introduction of this tax.
I believe it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I believe it is a significant responsibility.

now lies in the Council’s hands to act actively, and I would like to use my allotted time to appeal to the Council to do everything possible to ensure that this control is actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.

Dear colleagues,

when considering all the detail problems—matters about which we can certainly talk and which will still need to be discussed in the further legislative process—we should agree on a
be clear. Financial markets cannot function according to this model. If everything goes well, banks pocket the profits, and if something goes wrong, taxpayers foot the bill.
Therefore, it makes sense to also subject financial transactions to taxation.
And it makes sense to do that across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we will not experience disruptions, but rather that we will continually contribute to establishing a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for, namely that companies

Access to capital, ensuring that savers have the opportunity to put something aside or to set funds aside for retirement, and that financial markets once again fulfill the task for which they were originally created, namely, to provide added value for the real economy.
All of that which drove us into the financial crisis were products that created no value for the real economy.

Therefore, it makes sense to consider a tax, a contribution towards ensuring that this is heavily penalized, that it is sanctioned, that it is regulated – in the sense that capital once again fulfills its role.
today, I am advocating for this proposal with a significant majority.
The reform of the general preference system was certainly necessary.
It is now beneficial that there are longer durations and increased security for export goods.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the development committee has already stated.
The Commission unfortunately refers only to World Bank classifications.
In this regard, Parliament has repeatedly and critically examined the gross domestic product as the sole criterion in the past.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with 4 or up to 12 Gross National Income.
This represents, therefore, a vast and far too broad range, and does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
That countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are discovering flight, we certainly do not find concerning.
The reform in that direction was therefore positive.
But these countries are high-income countries, anyway.
Russia and China are countries against which, however, with elevated middle incomes. Regarding their potential exit from the APS, we certainly need not worry about that.
But this category of countries also includes considerably poorer nations, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Until now, the Commission has also considered the vulnerability criterion, that is, countries that export little or only a very limited range of goods.
This at least helps avoid countries that are less dependent on the export of a few products and are very vulnerable from being rated too highly.
Why did the Commission then strike this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji Islands, Gabon, and Botswana will therefore be excluded, despite their economies falling under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why did the commission not continue the existing criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
The suspicion arises that the Commission intends to force poorer countries into free trade agreements that are disadvantageous to them.

However, the preference system is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development pathway of a country or region plays no role whatsoever.
However, there may still be an opportunity for colleagues in the plenary session to approve our amendment, which incorporates vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also results in trade regions being fragmented.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to adhere to different rules when exporting to the EU.
That has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The commission should increasingly consider development regions rather than individual countries.
Here, too, we from GRNE have submitted an amendment proposal that we hope will garner much support.
It is also problematic when countries that yesterday still benefited from the APS are to be excluded from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and we see in our own countries that a few months are not sufficient for economic development.

Ultimately, however, we, as members of parliament, must also consider whether, in all legislative proposals, we want to focus solely on speed and then work with crooked compromises, or whether we would prefer to involve the entire assembly.

I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation and for democracy, and it is not time or speed that are important, but rather time is needed to enforce democracy and to properly enact laws.

Mr. President, High Representative! I, too, was a member of the European Parliament’s observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to ascertain the immense hope and expectations for a better future with which people lined up and waited at the polling stations to cast their votes.
We now know that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as our colleague Nidelschewa did in her report.
The previous year’s president, Josef Kabila, declared himself the election winner. The opposition is being suppressed.

In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again.
Whether third-party states, such as Rwanda, are involved remains unclear.
Those who suffer are, in any case, the civilian population, which has now for decades been unable to live in peace and quiet.
The country’s wealth is squandered in a torrent of corruption. The Congo remains, in all assessments at the international level, among the very last.

International organizations, here particularly the European Union with its capabilities, must increase the pressure on the President of the Republic of the Congo to establish genuine democracies in order to allow the country to participate. He did so at the next regional elections.
and that the Congolese army does not also harass the civilian population, but instead apprehends internationally wanted criminals against humanity like Bosco and Ganga and brings them before a court.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to ensuring no further weapons are delivered to the Congo.
Without external pressure, the human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues! The TuPEC aims to establish further overriding powers against crisis countries within the Eurozone.
The European Semester, created as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be sharpened.
According to the Commission’s intention, Member States should be able to be compelled to accept financial assistance.
The Six Pack has already established extensive sanctioning possibilities that can be imposed on Eurozone states facing financial difficulties.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a sensible instrument for coordinating economic policy.
Simultaneously, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with exclusion from the Eurozone should they make the wrong decision in Sunday's election.
Why don’t we stop with these degrading and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically intensified—I think of Spain, of Cyprus—it does us no good to put member states already struggling in the crisis on display.
We should finally develop solutions. The rapporteurs of TuPEEC have indeed developed sensible approaches to this end.
Elisa Ferreira's reference to the redemption fund is certainly warranted. That would be a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
I have also considered John Paul Gose’s proposal for an orderly state insolvency.
is that Europe is undertaking a collective and solidarity-based effort to return the Eurozone to a path of growth.
The stronger nations in Europe must cease to be complacent and point fingers at their partner countries.
You must begin doing your homework, invest in growth, and take responsibility.
The one-sided austerity policy of all Merkel governments has simply failed as a solution to the crisis.

Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues! In June 2010, the heads of state or government of the EU finally recognized the need for a better coordinated financial and economic policy within the European Community.
At the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is, of course, entirely correct that members of an Economic and Monetary Union must not solely focus on how their policies affect businesses, employees, and consumers within their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.

An internal market without coordination in economic remuneration and social policy presents member states with a significant temptation, namely to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can drive the monetary union to economic and political failure.
And the EU is currently facing precisely such a situation.

For years, the German economy has drained the resources of its neighbors, providing no impetus through investment and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has almost driven the Eurozone to ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.
Therefore, it is encouraging that the Commission is now gradually addressing this core problem of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making corresponding proposals.

It is only right that the Federal Republic is called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare. It is also only right that the Commission is called upon to stop the misuse of mini-jobs and to adjust wage growth to productivity growth.
This is a later, but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will vigorously represent these demands to the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen! Firstly, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission, particularly to Commissioner Barnier, for a very simple reason: the experience from the previous parliamentary term, the one preceding 2009,

That was, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening, the proposal from the European Private Company – the predecessor of Mr. Commissioner Barnier, Mr. Commissioner Merkrivi – effectively put company law into a deep slumber. We spent these five years on this crucial question, which is of importance to the single market.
have progressed.
Fortunately, that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there is a variety of consultation documents from the European Commission, and an expert group that had been formed to consider the further development of company law. We now have a very current consultation, with which, as Parliament, we are naturally also concerned.
The Legal Committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, and that simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this topic with the Commission, with Mr. Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time, to clearly define our position as Parliament in a subsequent resolution regarding what should now happen.

I believe that it is necessary, similarly to what we have experienced once before, approximately ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European social law, and that for a variety of reasons.
There are gaps within European social law – gaps in the literal sense – which essentially result in the internal market not being established.
I want to cite the example of the absence of the 14th Directive on Relocation of Registered Offices, which is usually a highly typical example of such a loophole.
Parliament has demanded twice in the legislative initiative reports that concrete proposals from the European Commission be put forward on this matter.
There is also the expert group, which the European Commission itself appointed, that likewise held the same view on this matter.
It simply belongs to the fundamental freedoms of the internal market that a company within the internal market must also be able to move, with regard to its registered size.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this backdrop, however, I must simultaneously criticize the fact that the European Commission’s previous response to Directive 14 has actually fallen significantly short of Parliament’s expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard of a reasoned answer to a legislative initiative.
But we are optimistic that, within the scope of further work, should an action plan materialize, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the continued development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens on businesses.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example, on the topic of
Accounting. But I believe there is also more to do and further aspects that will now be clarified within the scope of the consultation.
Here, we also anticipate further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the commission to revive the topic of the European private company, which is currently stalled in the Council.

If there are individual Member States – and I may allow myself to express my own opinion here – if there are individual Member States within the EU that, due to a lack of their own decisiveness, are not capable of resolving the deadlock on their own.

To move Europe forward, one must, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, consider utilizing the instrument of enhanced cooperation, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the commission to reconsider this matter with particular attention.
Another open question is the issue of applicable law, that is, a sort of Rome Regulation for cross-border problems in corporate law.
I also believe that this question requires further investigation and discussion, and would ask the commission to do so.
That is also closely related.
The insolvency law, but there is already an announcement that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission within a foreseeable timeframe.
You see, within company law, there is much work to be done regarding norms.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has once again taken the initiative, and it is evident that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can then represent progress in shaping the single market.
The parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
Regarding the details, one will naturally also. And that we must, we will certainly do.
But many thanks to the commission as well.
We would, of course, be delighted if the Commission were to take up our initiatives and translate them into concrete proposals.
Dear Commissioner, I greatly appreciate your suggestion regarding a productivity-based wage policy.
But on the issue of the minimum wage, you reneged on your promise to Mrs. Merkel, and I don’t believe you regarding the expansion of employment in the healthcare sector.
How can new work possibly emerge there, when the Commission has already compelled southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by as much as half?

How can employment in the healthcare sector arise, when the Commission, in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, deems it necessary for some Member States to further reduce expenditure on healthcare?
I fear this point in this plan is pure announcement politics, no real initiative for new work.
On the contrary, even today, due to austerity measures, there is a shortage of medical supplies and medication not only in Greece.
I believe that whoever consistently establishes new safety nets for banks must now focus on a safety net for the people, particularly for securing medical care in crisis-stricken countries.
The sentiment among countless pro-Europeans, like myself, is one of frightened dismay over what is currently happening in Europe.
It is, at the very least, gratifying that what we are dealing with is now stated much more clearly, and that the eyes are not closed even regarding Italy.

You are aware yourselves that a number of cases are involved, not only those concerning debt and growth, but also those concerning trust and the trap of power, assessed by the Commission and also addressed to the Council.
You have, unfortunately, so far failed to address the central question of separating the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here will be repeatedly assessed in expert opinion, and it remains the case that no serious limits have been placed on the shadow banking sector.
We are also dealing with systemic risks. Furthermore, the question of “too big to fail” has not been adequately addressed, and there is little point in discussing the rating agencies.

I can only urge you, as you now work toward the European Council meeting, to also advise on restoring credibility in Europe by seriously addressing this power dynamic between the real and financial sectors.
To put it succinctly, that you are finally working in a credible way before the European citizens to ensure that banks are held accountable and that it is not always the citizens who bear the burden.

For it, one can, from the country that rejected the Euro, nevertheless argue with the central justification that one wishes to preserve the flexibility of devaluation, particularly for reasons relating to socio-political instruments.

In light of the experiences you have now gained in Sweden, would you advise the Greeks to also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively utilize this socioeconomic instrument of devaluations accordingly?
Thank you, Mr. President! I would also like to express my sincere gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environmental Committee by a substantial majority, with 62 votes in favor, 0 votes against, and no abstentions.
That demonstrates that we are, in fact, very, very closely aligned there, even regarding compromises.
Naturally, the highest priority in these legislative procedures must be a high level of protection, strong consumer protection, particularly for the vulnerable members of our society – our children.
And as far as gluten intolerance is concerned, this is a problem, particularly in kindergartens.
Looking around, I have two children of this age, and considering the allergies and intolerances that prevail there, I believe we made the right choice.
We should also discuss this together in the second reading, with the council and the committee.
I believe that we will also arrive at a good result.
Heartfelt thanks! A report on a traffic accident over the weekend involving a truck driver who fell asleep due to exhaustion and veered into the roadside ditch has once again confirmed how necessary.
a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control via its digital tachograph is essential for traffic safety, but also for those affected.
The digital Dachograf represents a certain innovation. It presents new problems, but also retains old ones.
The new problems arise from novel opportunities for manipulation, which we must also bring under technical control.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, during or due to a lack of control in various member states.
What we are now newly regulating, in my view, has to be considered significantly. Firstly, that not every time when no journey is recorded, a rest period automatically ensues.
For many drivers involve loading and unloading, and this is naturally to be considered working time.
The second problem is that the speed records have been removed from the file.
I consider that to be incorrect, as significant accident risks exist here as well.
We would also like to have weight sensors, and we would also like to have a hotline so that fraud can be reported, anonymously and tracked.
What I will also propose is that animal transport controls be incorporated into this regulation.
I consider this important, because it is also a central element of our legislation.

Madam President! Many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not suffer permanent disabilities had professional medical assistance been provided quickly enough, that is to say within the first so-called “golden hour,” after their accident.
We would be a significant step closer to Vision Zero.
Now, the eco system—regarding which we are speaking today—cannot prevent accidents. It also does not absolve one of the duty to provide first aid.
It serves solely to automatically inform an emergency call center in the event of a severe accident.
This must also establish verbal contact with the accident vehicle to avoid misuse and overload due to battery accidents.
What if the emergency call is confirmed or no one responds any longer, emergency physicians are dispatched to the scene of the accident equipped with limited, but life-saving, information.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain rests with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the ecosystem remains dormant, meaning it transmits no signals or data and cannot be located.
It is, therefore, also significantly superior from a data protection perspective compared to a mobile phone.
The system activates either automatically via sensors or through conscious manual triggering.
It then transmits a pre-agreed minimum dataset of information to a rescue coordination center.
Europe-wide uniform standards and specifications will ensure that these data are recognized, assessed, and handled as emergency calls upon arrival.
Therefore, member states must also upgrade and expand their emergency service chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU-wide emergency number 112, to be free of charge for users, to function throughout the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
These can also subsequently support other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or parking availability.

In recognition of the automotive industry’s outstanding achievements in providing in-vehicle emergency call systems, these should retain their justification alongside the public2 systems throughout their existence.
Users can also opt for such a system based on detailed information.
This may be accompanied by costs where applicable.
Temporary use of data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services, or other service providers.
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem that we have created for ourselves today.

For if this brewery or beverage distributor is 107 kilometers from my place of residence, I will no longer have any chance that he will continue to offer me his goods in the future without having to purchase a new tachograph, without any new bureaucracy.

Therefore, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today, because I am of the opinion that we should not impose too much on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many points that we were able to incorporate, which were positive!
They were, after all, planned to accept only distances of fifty kilometers within the range of a regional provider.
That was utterly absurd on the part of the EU Commission.

because, for example, the individual who provides goods for the construction or beverages for the breweries has their entire workday completely monitored via GPS.

Thank you very much for this question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision.
I awaited the European People's Party’s approval in the Legal Affairs Committee while we were still posing the necessary questions concerning legal certainty regarding ACTA during the process.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
That is not what you wanted. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be employed to cause delay. That is clear.
Why did I say that about the broad scope for interpretation?
We must answer both questions, as you have posed two, and that is unfortunately the case.
because one can extract and interpret surveillance of the internet, auxiliary police officers, ISPs, and everything else from these extensive formulations.
And that means legal uncertainty, legal uncertainty doesn’t help our economy either, dear colleague!
Mr. Leichtpreter, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
Or are you entirely opposed to the rejection of all intellectual property?
How do you envision the e-commerce directive being adapted to modern circumstances in the future?
From your statement, I understand that you reject a debate on these matters altogether and do not uphold intellectual property.
Is that correct, or how?
Sir! It is becoming apparent. This is not merely a matter of individual facts that we must discuss, but of the fundamental question: How do we deal with democracy and with fundamental rights?
And when we examine ACTA, we find that it is, in a sense, symbolic of a lack of transparency, of a lack of democracy, and a violation of fundamental rights, because it was devised in secret.
and, in a sense, undemocratic, because the free use of the internet simply might no longer be possible, and also not the freedom to utilize generics to the extent that has been the case so far.
These are the reasons why millions of people took to the streets and have long since voted on ACTA.
Yes, there has been voting on ACTA – on the streets, online, regarding the petitions committee – in many countries, not only within the EU.
Also outside the EU. I believe we must not ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who have elected us.
I can only tell you to file ACTA away; that would be decent.

Madam President! As rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have completed two procedures under your presidency: the budgetary rules for the upcoming MFF period and the OLAV procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation had been pending in the Council, and you have brought this procedure to completion building upon the results of the Polish presidency.
I would therefore like to thank you for two truly, very, very dedicated tax officials who processed these files and also brought them to the attention of the ambassador.
You will be missed. His efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
You have truly earned the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen,

I am speaking here now as a representative of my parliamentary group and would like to support the motion proposed by my colleague Fehlner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This necessitates careful handling of the matter of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has put forward to us, to the European Court of Justice for an opinion to clarify still-open questions.
I believe that respect for the highest court of the European Union alone dictates that we await this decision.
There is, objectively speaking, no reason whatsoever to make this decision today.
No one will be prevented from dissenting once the court has presented its decision and statement.
But the decision that is then made occurs within a different consciousness and a different understanding than today’s.
I do not mean that rogue drivers on the internet autobahn should dictate our policies. Therefore, my request is to support this motion.
As always, when Kollege Turmes speaks, it is very astute, and one wishes that what he says had a much greater influence on European policy.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Naturally, these project bonds are a sensible idea, but only if they are sustainability-oriented and if the necessary political groundwork is also established.
We are running into danger by securing guarantees and risks that we do not have politically under control.

The energy transition in Germany would require a network of 8,380 kilometers, but only 100 kilometers of these corresponding high-voltage transmission lines have been built, partly due to resistance from citizens – incidentally, citizens with a strong environmental orientation.
We need to come up with something politically.

One idea would be to create shared transport corridors, meaning not just combining high-speed rail lines with broadband networks, but also constructing utility lines above them, alongside the motorway.
That, however, requires a far more comprehensive planning than has been provided thus far, but I would at least like to suggest it at this point.

Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements within the European Union. However, I am also aware that borders remain a very sensitive issue for our member states, and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems existing between member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And various problems exist.
And by ignoring, one does not make the problems better, nor does one solve them better.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and here, nobody would ever consider reclosing the border, simply because we are experiencing problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, and not for restrictions or corrections.
Covert surveillance has been established because we want to ensure security while simultaneously maintaining freedom of movement.

If we conduct the border surveillance successfully, I anticipate – specifically at the borders, including into the Czech Republic – that we will encounter more than a few drug dealers; this won't be an isolated occurrence, but rather
F attempts to gain access. Then I believe it would be good if the German Federal Interior Minister and the Czech composition number jointly resolve the problems that exist at the border.
And that should not have a regulatory effect on the Commission, but rather a positive, supportive effect.

We want to curb the populists, but resolve the problems among ourselves. Therefore, I also ask the Council to seek a solution together with the Parliament, so that we can successfully adopt the Schengen dossiers, ensuring freedom of movement and simultaneously guaranteeing the security of citizens.
The instances of disproportionate border checks, as listed by the Parliament in its question, also demonstrate why the Council wishes to exclude the Parliament from Schengen matters in principle.
The council intends, namely, to continue undermining freedom of movement without parliamentary involvement or any form of parliamentary oversight, without any form of transparency.
It is no wonder, then, that you prefer to pat yourselves on the back in backrooms, away from uncomfortable questions.
No wonder the German government wants to rule out an evaluation of the internal borders entirely and thus does not want to examine to what extent freedom of movement is restricted.
Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe, and therefore also belongs within the European Parliament. Thank you very much!

Dear President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christofs!

It is a special moment for me and my group today to be able to welcome you here in your function as President of the Council of the European Union.
We are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person at the head of the EU stands before us whom we can count among our political family.
You assume the presidency at a time when the European Union faces immense challenges, and it is necessary to set the course for whether the
whether it will actually have a future or whether it will prove to be a historical defeat, a footnote in history—that would be, from my perspective, a profound setback.
Following the discussions we have had with you, with representatives of your government, and with the chairpersons of the factions and parties in your country, I know that you have agreed on
We have prepared our presidency excellently and that you are also aware of the weight and significance of your task.
But, and you have made that clear here today, you intentionally want to direct the attention of those in power to the living situation of people.
I can tell you here, after everything I have heard in recent years, that it is the first time a President of the European Union actually does and announces and says this.

I have long missed this in official speeches—
that which is said is this: it concerns the people, it concerns those who are not responsible for the crisis we are in, yet who bear the brunt of it.
It will prove difficult to implement this very approach.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be gained, and you will do so as well, I am very certain, if you especially encourage people with your presidency and in such a way.
You exercise the fact that you stand up for your rights and that you contribute to ensuring that the Council, that the European institutions are keenly aware of this very task.
We repeatedly discuss the euro and its stability, the necessity of which I also see, for the functioning of the European Union and for the Eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which have been defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union to tolerate a situation where people within the European Union must suffer from hunger, where healthcare systems collapse, or where local administrations are forced to cease operations.
Something has become distorted.
It is not what we designate as the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that the focus must be on social cohesion and solidarity, both among the individual member states and between the most diverse population groups.
The European Union must not simply allow itself to be used as an instrument or as a spokesperson for a small, specific stratum of the population, nor present itself as such.

a final point I would also like to address, naturally, to underscore that everything you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us and that we will support the points that move in that direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people no longer live in fear.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
I believe that some decisions in recent weeks and months, particularly in the elections in Greece and the votes on the referendum in Ireland, were also shaped by fear.
And if those in power within the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Wishing you much success in your work.

Dear colleagues,

I believe we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs, working together.
Colleague, it will be very, very important in the coming weeks and months to work on this dossier swiftly and reliably.

Currently, eyes are on us and on the Council, regarding the decision to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step of European integration, specifically through a European Banking Union.
It should be noted that Parliament already requested this with a broad majority two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in that direction, but unfortunately not as far as would actually have been necessary.
Further billions in invoices have arisen as a result.
It is positive that the council has now drawn conclusions and wishes to further deepen this step for the Eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has developed the proposals so quickly.
The Council’s proposition that the ECB should become the location of the Eurozone supervisor is, however, associated with several difficulties.
In the council, this leads to unanimity and means that, in this dossier, the parliament is not involved in co-decision.
After the experiences with the supervisory package, this is unacceptable.

Therefore, it is important that we work swiftly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal regarding the changes at the ECB with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby establishing, in effect, the principle of parliamentary democratic participation.
Democratically, there are further challenges as well.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has not previously had any responsibilities.

If you now assume responsibility within banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, the right to question, and appointment rights; and I am certain that Parliament will assert these in a broad majority.

The complex questions regarding the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility, we will have to thoroughly regulate in the coming weeks. Thank you very much.
By proposing to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to incorporate these countries into free trade agreements.
These agreements, contrary to what the term “economic partnerships” suggests, concern only the interests of the EU and not the development interests of the partner countries.
That runs completely counter to the EU’s objective of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments accordingly.
Countries such as Cameroon, Côte d'Ivoire, and Namibia would be massively affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects, such as those in Southeast Africa, would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
The South Sudan Cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and simultaneously suggest that other countries should please buy our goods.
If the Commission genuinely believes that trade can foster development, then it should not block it.
The Committee on Development of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
we should join in on that in the plenary session.
Sir! Both in Central America and in Peru, Colombia, there are an immense number of problems in the area of human rights.
And we, as Members of the European Parliament, cannot simply turn a blind eye to this.
We will thoroughly examine the roadmap for human rights, requested by the EP in the cases of Colombia and Peru, once it has been drawn up.
It must possess substance and be binding, and include initial results, such as the conviction of perpetrators and the secure return of displaced persons to their land.
And, of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.
We Greens believe it is correct that the Committee on Trade is demanding environmental and social standards in the draft regulation on safeguard clauses and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue must then also confirm it, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
Above all, the EU must do far more to keep a close watch on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.
Therefore, we also demand from GRNE a proper impact assessment prior to each negotiation, one that examines not only the economic consequences for the EU, but also the effects on human rights.
Mr. Barroso, I made it quite clear in the first round what I would like to emphasize.
My concern is the expectation of my group from the Commission that it once again accommodates the troika in the relevant bodies to make it clear.

The Commission, as a European institution, bears the responsibility to ensure that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not reduced, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
This is your task.

If we succeed in making that clear, then we also send a signal to the people who, in their thousands and hundreds of thousands, are also protesting these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we, as a parliamentary group, also declare solidarity—whether in Thessaloniki or Barcelona.
This morning, I heard the news that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and striking.
Where have we arrived, that people experiencing profound social and personal distress can no longer receive any assistance or support, because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here, we must finally become active.
One more point: An approach held by many decision-makers is that the people in Greece and other countries have lived beyond their means.
We must be punished today and must endure sanctions.
It is unsuitable for strengthening a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not attributing this to you, Mr. Barroso, but it is an approach that is also prevalent in many countries and, unfortunately, recurs repeatedly in my own approach as well.
The chair, I confess, I have acted disastrously.
I do not wish to offer an explanation for this report, but rather to address the report by Morera concerning the Agreement on Immediate Autonomous Trade Preferences for Pakistan.
I would like to be called back again.

Madam President! The new directive establishes a framework for dealing with books, newspapers, works of art, films, musical pieces, and television productions that are subject to copyright but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or located.
Consequently, books, films, photographs, or other intellectual creations for which no rights holder can be found should also be made available to the public.
And thus, a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us in the Culture Committee, it was particularly important in this legislative initiative to highlight the special significance of the diversity of the European Union's cultural heritage.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting corporations, there are countless, unedited works, and they should not have been made available to date simply because the rights of the owners are not known.
That changes with the directive.
It will enable the future utilization of this cultural heritage asset, provided that a careful search is conducted prior to publication.
This is a very important point to ensure that it is not said lightly: We do not find rights holders.
For a balance had to be found with the very real rights of the creators of works and the need of the public as well to be able to utilize such works where the legal situation could not be clarified.
A particular focus for us has also been to ensure that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be located, the draft facilitates the digitization of orphaned works.
Projects like Europäer and other large European digitization projects, but also our museums, archives, and educational institutions, as well as public broadcasting, will flirt.
In the future, however, it must also address the issue of making the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers accessible to the public.
This draft guideline and the compromise now found, in my view, truly represent a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural heritage to which he belongs holds enormous potential.
We should also continue working on this during the revision of the guideline in two years.

Signals from the Council would show us how we can develop growth and competitiveness potential in Europe and, above all, how we could provide employment for young people again.

We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for that. I only see cuts here by the council.
Or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme, or the programme for media pluralism – here, there are only cuts.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by implementing cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is being proposed by Ratzeiten.
Where is this to be found within the household report submitted by the council?
Nordseewerk in Emmen was compelled to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was unexpectedly not extended.
This company, with 700 skilled positions, is undergoing a transformation from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a mass credit and that the jobs can also be saved. Because the colleagues at SIAC and Nordsee-Ewe have already had to accept considerable cuts regarding their salaries.

Therefore, I request that the Commission examine this procedure favorably, but also promptly, so that these 700 jobs are not jeopardized, because these 700 jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to develop sustainable energy sources on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues – women and men – suffer because of the state government’s poor crisis management.
Goods often appear innocuous, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can use them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile software from Nokia Siemens Network that fell into the hands of Iranian security forces, facilitating the suppression of the Green Movement protests.
Protectors were massively arrested, abducted, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And this is just one example among many.
Furthermore, the Commission is also promoting these questionable digital goods, as it claims, through the catalogue of measures for an innovative and competitive security sector.
The goal is, as it were, to establish better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy, practically selling off human rights, as well as our security interests.
Therefore, I would like to request that you approve the proposed amendments from us and the Social Democrats, as well as all others.
I would like to ask colleague Regner, what do you think trade unions could do, for example, to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will be insufficient.
What active role could the internal market play here?
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! I believe that with today’s debate on MiFID we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
This legislative period has seen proposals concerning the regulation of financial markets, rather than merely considering individual products, as we have done in the past.
I would like to mention just a few key terms.
We certainly didn’t make each other’s work very easy last year.

We conducted a hearing in committee, carried out an inquiry with all stakeholders and interested groups, and, based on this, developed a result—incorporating various processes, working documents, and similar elements—which we will present to the plenary session for a vote today and tomorrow.
I would like to highlight a few key points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

On the one hand, we must naturally acknowledge that she has done quite a bit in recent years in the area of financial markets, but our interest, as parliament, is that every transaction of financial instruments that takes place occurs within the MiFID regulatory framework. We are also, under many conditions, a new category.

We have agreed to so-called organised trading facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is prohibited, and where, according to statements regarding execution, transaction, and customer interaction, execution according to own discretion may take place.
I believe that we are thereby making an important contribution to ensuring that the entire area of over-the-counter (OTC) instruments that are traded is handled within the MiFID world.
Another significant topic not yet addressed in the previous MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here, too, our aim was to establish clear rules of engagement, ensuring that this area, which can be very dangerous and can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regulations with minimum holding periods.

Disruption possibilities for trading, with the opportunity to test algorithms, with the opportunity to examine algorithmic supervisory structures, with the introduction of a so-called TIC size regime, a minimum price increment, and through corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of warning time markets.

I do believe that we have a particular responsibility here when it comes to restricting the speculative element in genuine futures markets so that we do not contribute, through incorrect regulations, to a situation where people in the third and fourth worlds can no longer afford to buy food.
We have therefore chosen a two-pronged approach, aiming to curb speculation while avoiding harm to the real economy.
With position limits, with strict upper limits for the number of contacts or positions, we aim to achieve this.

However, we also want to ensure, for those who can demonstrate a genuine need for a product, that they do not suddenly engage in speculative activity within this market as well, through a so-called Position Check System.
Another topic that occupies us considerably is the area of investor protection.
I would merely like to point out here that we have adopted a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The objective here is to identify the needs of specific customer groups.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex financial instruments.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product reviews, telephone recordings, relevant consultations, disclosure obligations, but also, and I want to briefly mention this in the area of commissions, to apply the principle of subsidiarity.
Member States shall be entitled to make corresponding adjustments in accordance with their structures.
I believe that's us on the right track.
Once my time expires, I wish to thank all those who have contributed here.
I find it regrettable that one is so difficult, that everyone receives four minutes of speaking time.
I would like to thank all colleagues here at the Commission for their very constructive role in recent weeks and months.
I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow, we will be able to enter negotiations with the Council and conclude this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you.

Dear colleagues,

Thank you very much first and foremost for the generally good collaboration on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal that had already made significant progress in the right direction at key points.
Within the realm of market structures, there will be greater transparency, particularly comprehensive transparency in the area of derivatives trading.

Within the framework of MiFID, the resolutions in the area of high-frequency trading of our committee go considerably further than what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
Even in areas that have provoked considerable public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, following extensive and difficult debates—it must be said—much more has now been achieved than the Commission's resolutions, because position limits are now legally binding there.
We still require further adjustments in this area, however, to close any remaining gaps.
I also hope for further additions here through the plenary vote and ultimately also in the trilogue.
And it is gratifying that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament’s more far-reaching proposal.
However, the report’s weaknesses lie in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to prohibit products. That is a progress. However, we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven consulting.

How true it remains that the distribution of financial products is not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is strongly dominated by which product yields the highest commissions.
Even in Germany, but throughout the EU, consumers have lost a great deal of money.
Think of the open-ended real estate funds.
For citizens in countries like France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The fundamental principle will continue to be commission-based orientation.
To invoke subsidiarity here is rather simplistic.
I would have preferred stronger regulations here.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! Yes, what has long been desired finally turns out well, I can only say.
The report on the type approval of vehicles in category L has ultimately become a good report after all.
The work took longer overall than we all thought, and certainly longer than we hoped. And there were far more pitfalls than we ultimately would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to express my sincere gratitude once again to the rapporteur, Mr. Van der Kampf, for the truly cooperative and positive collaboration.
Together, we achieved a great deal in the negotiations with the member states nonetheless.
As rapporteur for my group, I recommend approving this report. Nevertheless, it could have been much better.
To put it more precisely, my esteemed colleagues.

For us Social Democrats, vehicle safety and, consequently, the safety of drivers—particularly the safety of scooter riders and drivers, and motorcycle riders and drivers—was our primary concern from the outset.
The number of unmarried motorcyclists, however, has remained constant for years.
In this case, the numbers of traffic fatalities in Europe are generally decreasing, but not in motorsport motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer fatalities on European roads – that was, and that is, my goal.
Every deceased person is one too many.
Especially in a regulation so advantageous for the internal market, this topic must be addressed intensively.
That this can be achieved through effective technologies, such as anti-lock braking systems (ABS), I remain convinced.
And I am equally convinced of the cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

We did, however, succeed in ensuring that, from 2016, all nine and from 2017, all existing motorcycle types with an engine displacement of 125 cubic centimeters or greater must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer.
With scooters, manufacturers could optionally equip them with either ABS or combined braking systems.
At this point, we must regrettably acknowledge that we have not achieved any improvements to the Commission’s proposal.
I would have wished for much more here. But the Commission and Member States have, to put it mildly, shown themselves to be very cumbersome.
We did, however, manage to have the Commission present a report in 2019.
The report must be fed with traffic accident data from the member states and should examine the mandatory installation of ABS on motor scooters.
It will also be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
Based on this report, the commission will then consider making the installation of ABS in vehicles mandatory.
You see, the topic remains very, very vibrant.
Therefore, we will endeavor to close the binding legislative gap beginning in 2019.
I am confident that the collected data will confirm my findings.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for riders of two wheels in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future.
Mr. President, Matthias Groth, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
And I believe that applies to what we are discussing today as well.
I strongly advocate for a rational discussion of this matter.
What we are currently experiencing is a new addition to the energy markets through unconventional resources, specifically in the case of gas—primarily gas, but also oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to succumb to great euphoria regarding a grand gas future. It is just as inappropriate as some of my colleagues from the Greens and Left Party have done here, painting horrific and dreadful scenarios that have nothing to do with reality.

I believe we must keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to transform all existing energy supply relationships between providers and consumers, and that the economic viability calculations of previous energy sources are being called into question.
We must confront this development.

I believe that we should acknowledge that this can also be an opportunity for Europe, and not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to view and utilize new technologies positively, to fairly weigh opportunities and risks, and to avoid falling into ideological debates. Thank you.
Mr. Commissioner, thank you for your response. It does not entirely satisfy me.
For I consider a year a very, very long timeframe between the notification that a complaint has been received and potentially receiving a response so late.
I believe that a complainant, who has gone to the trouble—and usually has already exhausted all legal avenues in their member state—deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If you do it in this manner, we should treat it accordingly.

I believe it is necessary and essential in the long term that we have here a procedure which is clearly formalized and which clearly regulates the rights. This is now a declaration of how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point, I have nothing against it, if it serves the purpose, that one attempts to achieve a kind of amicable clarification with the member states together.
However, that will not always be sufficient.
We observe that it proceeds relatively swiftly, for example, in economic matters, when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

But when it comes to environmental issues and similar questions, where a very large number of citizens demand the activity of the European Union or, indeed, social rights, then that progresses somewhat more laboriously, with caution.
I believe that these facts, too, must be clearly considered.
I would like to see, for your next report, a clear formalization of the complainant’s rights vis-à-vis the commission—one that is truly explicit and effectively communicated.
Once again, if we genuinely want European law to be applied, after we have put so much process here in the European Parliament, in the Council—
We have jointly decided. Then we must inform those who are concerned with it, those who are truly, so to speak, engaged at the European level, as thoroughly and precisely as possible.
This is a matter of great, great importance to me.
I will also carefully observe what has developed here next time.
Mr. President, colleagues! Five years ago, the European Union’s Central Asia Strategy was launched.
When assessing the balance sheet of this strategy today, the assessment is mixed.

We observe how the member states, individually, strive to establish good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries of this region, while, on the other hand, progress in these efforts is not advancing.
to accompany states in their transformation process toward modern democratic societies, or as recent events in Kazakhstan demonstrate, the development is even marked by regressions.

Nevertheless, and precisely for this reason, the European Union and the Member States must express their influence in this region more strongly and jointly, including, particularly, towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a key supplier for several EU states.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only lead to competitors exerting their influence even more strongly than previously in this geopolitically important country, for whom pressing for the observance of civil and human rights is of less importance.
The linkage of economic interests with the commitment to safeguarding citizens’ rights is the core element of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also form the basis for further negotiations regarding a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.

The present report provides good orientation on this matter.
Heartfelt thanks.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council! Perhaps you are following us via the Parliament's videostream, as you clearly have neither the capacity nor the inclination to speak with us live.
I regard the Council's absence here and now as a gross disrespect towards Parliament.
Instead of evading this debate, you should rather reveal your reasons for rejecting any improvement of the protection of personal data in the area of police and justice through a directive.

Police and justice have for years—we know this—been a haven for violations of data protection, not only at SWIFT, but for example daily in instances where data of citizens, who for example demonstrate against Nazis, are illegally collected and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors, and for police and justice. This is about guaranteeing civil rights.
If you request the Council to constructively participate in data protection-relevant regulations such as EU, PNA, or Europol, then conversely, this must also apply to the Council.
Therefore, I urge you to put an end to the policy of obstruction in the area of data protection.
